text: the appearance for a novice was very good , exactly what i imagine a stout should look like .  on the palate , this one is fairly light bodied with flavors of tart cherries , prunes , raisins and lightly roasted malt .

pours reddish light brown , appearance is closest to a belgian dubbel in my opinion , which may be a consistent characteristic . nose is strong on the bourbon which is a definite plus in my book - so often these bourbon aged beers dont carry as much of the characteristic .  m - a medium mouthfeel and rather smooth like caramel .
a : chocolate syrup brown with dense , oatmeal-colored 1-finger head that retains well and sheets the glass .  mouthfeel : thin and watery , but the carbonation is very crisp .
pours a deep rusty amber color , with a thick , foamy , sticky eggshell white head .  thinner body .

i had this beer poured from a bottle into a pint glass ... a : the beer is an orange hued golden with a small white head which quickly fades away to nothing ... s : the smell is nice . tart citric fruit and a sweet artificial apricot smell ... t : the taste is the same as the smell just a little muted .  m : has medium to full body with very little carbonation to make my mouth tingle .

clear mahogany with a mat of creamy off-white head that lasts and leaves plenty of lace behind .  the roast flavors give way to a hop bitterness in the finish with virtually no malt backbone in between . hints of licorice and coffee give this nice complexity for a lager . m- a little fuller than your typical schwarzbier . d- it drinks like a big beer , much more so than it 's 4.9 % abv would lend you to expect . overall : this is a very flavorful schwarzbier . my personal criticisms are that i would like it to have a little more malt in the middle while toning down the roast malts just a little . still , not a bad beer by any means .
young 's double chocolate stout pours a very dark brown with a nice , fluffy , light tan head .  m - coarse throughout but not as sticky as i would like from an imperial ipa .

a - poured , it looks like black coffee .  m -- maybe i should n't have drank this after sipping on a j.w . its not quite what i would call `` watery , '' but it could use a little more body . carbonation levels are fine .
pours a nice reddish amber with a very thik head that lasts quite a while .  only criticism : powerful aggressive carbonation , would it ease if i left it a while - just too fresh ?

aroma is intense , with a major blast of fruity hops coming through at first . apricots and grapefruit aromas along with alcohol making itself known in the background . there is a vodka type taste going on here with the alcohol , which detracts from an otherwise great tasting brew . nice job from rogue on giving this a totally different hop taste than all there other ales , which seem to have a distinctly unique hop profile .  you could certainly taste the chocolate , but it did n't fill the mouth with the heavy , rich bitter chocolate of some other beers in this same vein . i enjoyed drinking this beer ; it went down easily , but if given the choice , i would take the brooklyn chocolate stout , which is more like comfort food in the fall when it 's getting cold and the leaves are dying . this is supposed to be a beer you can snuggle with next to the fireplace while watching monday night football .

s - aroma is near perfection . there is definitely some underlying jp funk in the beer with slight tart notes . the belgian aspect to this beer is awesome in the nose . hints of banana bread some cinnamon rolls and gingerbread . awesome nose . t & m - wow .  hellooo hops ! this is a nice beer that hits you with hops right off the bat . nice hops with a touch of malt , and a lingering hop influenced aftertaste . i ca n't help but pick the slightest metallic twinge in the flavor and aftertaste , not sure where that could be coming from . not a bad strong ale at all , definitely worth revisiting but probably not distinguishable enough to stand in the upper echelon of style .

a thin bubbly tan head disappates quickly , though lots of carbonation is visible . the aroma is quite sweet , reminding me of caramel , burnt sugar , and malt . a unique rendition , but not what i look to get from the style .  the mouthfeel is light also and thin .
the huge head has all sizes of bubbles and demonstrates impressive retention and lacing .  mouthfeel is very acidic , carbonated .

hop wallop bottle to glass hop wallop looks like a fizzy yellow beer . smells of freshly cut grapefruit and citrus. , pineapples , lemons . nice and rounded .  sour dishwater . i do n't think this beer can be rated because it is marginally spoiled . the bacterial taste is taking over whatever else it might have once tasted like . i think bayhawk has a problem with some of their bottled ales , and they seem to be happy to leave them on the shelves for the unwary to buy . i 'm going to look at my usual san diego retailers to see where i paid $ 3.99 for this . this is the second of their beers i have tried and it too will water the garden .

great retention and lots of coating , spongy lace .  still , it seems a little light in body and the carbonation is low . without a doubt another quality beer by dogfish head , but i have a feeling that the pricetag of a 750 ml bottle would scare me from its purchase .

poured into a harpoon chalice , formed a 1 '' bright white head over the slightly cloudy light gold brew . head meringues up even further for awhile , with thick coating lace .  my new pbr.ha . joke , but .. ill change the details later . it 's from a can , but.. please , please pour it into a glass . it is great . it is economical . enjoy responsibly . ... ... great beer . i really want to talk abotu it , .. but i dont have the time right now.. please let me just post my ratings . yes .

s- perfect . a hop monster being over taken quickly by malty goodness . t- amazingly hoppy and bitter , but still almost balanced by caramel malt that makes it delicious .  the body seemed a bit light , and maybe a bit more weight would have made it more satisfying , but that 's a minor quibble .
from the bottle . poured black with a small tan head with some lacing .  m - thin on the mouth , ok carbonation .

it is true to the style and smelled fantastic . it was called flowers and damnit it smelled like flowers ! overall it is worth getting if you can find one , very unique .  m- near dead flat . it seems to be a bit on the thin side as well . d- despite the feel this beer still drinks deadly smooth .

a - pours a clear golden color with a thick bubbly head and good lacing . excellent appearance for this type of beer .  think prunes and raisins , but more complex and infinitely boozier . i ca n't believe that this beer is appearing thin on the palate and i think that it has to be with the insanely high abv . even though it 's clean , it 's still very sweet . i am loving the taste but i am certainly not digging the mouthfeel , that is into the moderate strength liqueur territory . a brewing achievement but not beer like ; delicious nonetheless .

appearance : pours a crystal clear pale gold with a fluffy white head on top . the head settles to a full cap with tons of spider web lacing covering the entire glass .  mouthfeel is oily and slick , and a little fizzy .
a perfect look for an impy .  low , easy-going carbonation .

( s ) - a seriously rich raisin and molasses profile with a heavy caramel and brown sugar sweetness . bits of vanilla , wood , and dark cocoa in the far background . i love the smell , but everything else is rather mediocre . this is so thick that it is hard to put down .  m - average carbonation .

smell : the smell is very complicated . i got notes of hops , and some very intense herbs ( corriander , rosemary , sage ) as well as an over all sweetness .  m : a little out of style ... pretty light bodied with good carbonation .

pours a deep red-orange with a one-finger white head that lingers throughout .  this beer really needs to sit a while before the mouthfeel is anywhere near decent . when its freshly poured and a bit too cool , it 's thin and prickly , but just letting it sit a while and come closer to room temp. , it becomes a bit fuller and mellows out a bit . really drinkable ris that has tons of flavor and a decent mouthfeel , once it warms up .
nose is a perfect balance of malt pollen , floral hop , and citrus fruit .  it kind of explodes in the mouth and the carbonation is a bit on the sharp side .

complex sour with tropical aromas . nice lacy appearance in the chalice with good carbonation in the mouth . what is that suddenly familiar aroma ? i flashed on cutting a passion fruit in half and smelling it . more nose of pineapple guava . one of the best and most interesting beers i 've tried this year .  high carbonation is the only downfall i can find in this beer .

smell is moderately malty , a bit sweet . straw , grass , silage , raw starchy grains , a little lemon and maybe some floral notes . a unique and appealing nose , like standing in a hay field .  light body and a bit watery , but the munich possesses a david-like flavor that surprises those who order it expecting something more saccharine .
beautiful color too .  slick mouth feel , very drinkable .

looks beautiful . fluffy white head compliments the golden body .  the mouthfeel , as with the question , keeps this from being a world class brew . the aroma and flavor are sublime but the carbonation detracts from the beer . i 'm looking forward to trying this with proper carbonation and we 'd be talking about an unbelievable beer .

one of the best looking brews i know of . deep chestnut brown-to-black . lovely , long-lasting , frothy-creamy , cream-colored head . good with food , on a hot day as a thirst-quencher/heat beater ( really !  m ) this beer is suprisingly thing considering the nature of the style . it does , however , have a very nice wet sticky and lingering feel .

s - this is all about anise . some cocoa tries to pop through . t - anise , root beer , cocoa and cough syrup , the latter i did n't care much for at all . small bitter in finish , but kinda cloying . d - was happy to try .  small amounts of a watery feel are noticed towards the back , overall has a decently appealing mouthfeel .

great big roasty aroma , a bit of chocolate .  sweet maple syrup aroma with herbal hops and some yeast . the malts have a very sweet taste and also there is a toasted bread taste that really develops in the aftertaste . very good ale !
very appealing . mouth : taste is fruity but too sweet .  mouthfeel - light for a winter seasonal brew , but not bad .

poured this from the 1 pt 9.4 oz corked bottle in a flute . appearance : this brew resembled to every detail a very rich italian espresso , both the color of the beer and the color of the head . the beer is a deep espresso brown , with tiny espresso foam colored carbonation rising to the top . gave it a couple swirls and head bounced right back . so resilient !  m - disappointing , frankly .

nose is a wonderful smoothe hoppy feel with some honey vanila notes that a very inviting . huge hoppy bite enters the mouth with a bang . a very favorable beer if you nare a hop head .  mouthfeel : smooth with a relatively full body .
i really like the nice brown and clear looking beer . looked very appealing .  mouthfeel is good , but not great , almost leaves a little alcohol flavor at the end and a little carbonated .

this is a very attractive brew . very dark , almost onyx black , but some hits of red with shown to light . inch head that looks like the coffee froth atop a well made espresso .  i found this beer to be one of the easiest-drinking beers i 've ever had . now , my review is flawed because i do n't believe i have any other saison/farmhouse ales to compare it to - this is my first . but from the description of the style , i expected something a bit more complex in flavor , and this was not complex at all . low abv combined with a mellow flavor equals very easy drinkability . for an every day summer beer , i 'd choose this hands down over the bmc beers ; unfortunately this runs $ 32 a case , so it could be come an expensive habit .

if this batch tasted like the wonderfully fresh hoppy aroma , i 'd be giving it a better tast rating .  mouthfeel : light bodied with moderate carbonation , slightly drying leaving that coffee dryness on the palate .

aroma is quite hoppy and very sweet with a hint of alcohol but the alcohol is well masked by the hops . the overall beer is quite good too .  matching , but mild , after-taste m-medium creamy carbonation . somewhat watery finish . the carbonation really bothered me with this one also .
s : big nose of raisins , prunes and burnt sugar .  mouthfeel is on the thin sider , and a bit oily , but there 's enough carbonation to keep it pleasant .

tawny pumpkin color with a splendid off-white head . great retention and insane lacing , sheets of foam everywhere .  pale straw with a fizzy head . no retention however and lacing is nowhere to be found . smells like the business end of a skunk . i tried several times to find anything else , but seemed to fail gracefully . taste is grassy and grainy . strange bitterness that did n't really seem like hops . yuck ! i was looking for cans to try and avoid the skunk aroma , but only found the evil green bottles . i will try this again someday when i work up the courage ... but it wo n't be from a bottle .

smells like a delicious tart raspberry . it has a very framboise-like aroma . nice tart fresh raspberry flavor upfront followed by a rather weak / bland malt base .  m : creamy , light , and watery on the palate .

perfect appearance : clear , golden orange , light amber , with a pillowy , tight off-white head that leaves messy , crooked lines of lace all the way down the glass .  mouthfeel medium -light mouthfeel with prickly carbonation . a bit too carbonated for my taste in a mild , but not too far off .

bottle smell is delicious , fruity , citrusy , some grapefruit and grapes , zesty . this hopping is very different . the aromas are citrusy but the flavor is more like a fuggles , or english ale , and the bitterness is very dry .  thin even for this style , i 'd like to see just a little more intensity in the backbone . mouthfeel : as you 'd imagine as you watch it pour , this is very much light-bodied . good carbonation and a clean finish .

s : great smell of aged caramel malt . heavy on the dark fruit , hard candy . t : similar to the smell , but not as sweet as the nose would imply .  body is medium with a decent amount of carbonation .

two-finger brown head on top settles quickly into a dense , creamy cap that has ridiculous retention . this one looks simply amazing .  m : mouthfeel is where this loses points . very thin but good carbonation .

smell : aroma of creamy , semi-sweet chocolate , sugar cookie dough , and heavily roasted grains . taste : a nice blend of dark chocolate and roasty coffee overtones .  light to medium carbonation , with a creamy mouthfeel on the tongue and in the mouth which leans towards crisp and almost watery in the overall feel to it .
appearance - pours a dark ruby with a creamy cratered tan head , lots of sticky lacing .  the beer is a little above average in drinkability , but the mouthfeel left much to be desired .

nice amber color ... nice head ... nice lace that sticks to the glass long after it 's empty .  it looks very inviting , dark brownish-reddish body , semi hazy and is topped off with a semi thick tan head that 's very bubbly and sticks around for a bit ; it has some strong lacing qualities . it has a medium to light mouth feel , clean and has mild carbonation . faint hops are present some roasted oats and grains , its sweet overall and no alcohol flavors , not even i the aftertaste .

taste isnt as good as the aroma but still nice . more roastiness but not overly roasty , figs , chocolate , caramel , some weak hops ... tad thin .  mouthfeel is a bit on the watery side , but not too bad .

s : a very nice floral nose with strong notes of cloves and spice with a gentle phenolic smell . t : grainier tasting than most with a spicy taste and a finishing flavor of banana .  this 'beer ' is weak . this 'beer ' is flavourless . no wait , i can taste some corn syrup , and what 's that ... pickle juice ? honestly , i think i taste hints of pickle juice !
superb color , a cloudy ghosty orangey brown topped by a foamy off-white head .  mouthfeel is medium bodied , slightly syrupy , and carbonation is low which produces a somewhat still feel .

nose is great , offering bold notes of bitter chocolate , coffee , and roasted malt with secondary characteristics of anise and molasses . still a damn good beer , but this there 's so much fierce competition in the style that , for me , you really have to earn your as .  mf- lower carbonation than i was expecting right out of the gate . mouthfeel was the only slight flaw .

the smell is quite sweet , very tart with a smell of , you guessed it , peaches . a great smelling fruit beer .  i gave the mouthfeel a lower score due to the extremely bitter after-taste and the thin-ness of the body .

12 oz bottle poured into a mug a : pours a very deep amber/copper with about two fingers of light tan head . lots of lacing and good head retention .  a light to medium body , with prickly , active carbonation . the carbonation was just a tad bit higher then i would have liked , but was still enjoyable .

poured black with no light passing through . wonderful tan , frothy head which diminished to nice lacing .  bought at whole foods , pasadena , ca-arroyo parkway . the taste is hoppy with a nice back end . can feel the abv in this pour . nice . i would drink this again .

appearance is a darker amber red with a pillowy head that sticks around leaving great lace .  got some from my daughter in texas as a christmas gift - it drinks well without filling you up . i poured it into a pilsner glass for a head of an inch or so . as a porter and stout drinker , i was surprised at the lightness of it given the color , but then , it 's a lager . i 'd like this on on a warm summer day .
very beautiful to look at . the color is just awesome !  the mouth is quite prickly and fairly heavy , even cloying a bit .
a- nice pour ... 5-finger head , nice espresso color and a great deep brown body .  the mouthfeel is a bit watery , but more substantial than most light beers .

bottle ( 2011 ) a beautiful rich copper color and a thick and stubborn off-white head . leaves gobs of lacing down the glass .  and a bit thin d-easy and enjoyable , drinks almost like a session ale .

a - pours with a ridiculous amount of tan foam that takes forever to dissipate and leaves a good amount of lacing .  slightly creamy body , though it falls flat at the front of the palate . it could use ( i ca n't believe i 'm saying this ) a bit more carbonation . or more body .
smooth , smooth , smooth ... and lots of malt . extremely creamy head . good hop bitterness in the finish to balance it out .  taste and mouthfeel : medium bodied , mid level carbonation .

pours a dark but brilliant red with a tannish 1 finger head .  consequently , the body was found to be light , yet the beer was flavorful , with a nice , almost malty , finish . the mouthfeel was similar to what one would find in most of the american large brew beers .

slightly sweet caramel , with a big oak woodiness , intense , spicy hops in the back , with hints of crisp citrus , earthy pine , and sweet buttery breads . while the aroma favored the oaked bigfoot , the taste seems to favor the pa/ipa side more . it then mellows out to those slightly sweet , earthy oak characters . white still great and wonderfully unique , i do n't think it achieved perfect synergy .  mouthfeel - medium bodied , very softly carbonated , gets a bit watery as it warms , which is a disappointment . lighter body than expected ( and preferred ) as a result .

appearance : the pour gives a 0.3 '' off white head that gradually falls back , though never quite all the way ... leaving a nice layer behind for awhile . the beer is a bright medium amber in color .  the taste was strong sour vinegar with some cherry and alcohol flavors . this one upset my stomach and i think this 2005 vintage was past its prime . god only knows what it was like fresh . this beer was not good and i happen to like sour beers .
big foamy off white head , good retention . bright reddish copper in color .  m : sticky , slight aftertaste .
awesome . taste- greeted with the normal citrusd peel , but more emphasis on grapfruit zest and some malts .  mouthfeel is medium bodied with some carbonation on the tongue .

the aroma is breathtaking . a beautiful balance of oak , sweet malt , and dark fruit with a layer of very clean smelling whisky gently overlaying the rest of the aromas . just marvelous . unfortunately , the taste fell a good deal short of the ethereal aromas .  this is an above-average premium bitter that , with a little more body and a less watery mouth feel , might have been a masterpiece .

smells absolutely delicious ! t : i sure wish it tasted more like it smelled .  the worst part is , right out of the bottle , it 's prickly and way too fizzy , though it has adequate body . while it 's not spectacular , this is a moderately refreshing , sessionable choice that rivals hoegaarden if i want a low-priced wit .

a- i believe to be one of the most beautiful looking beers , a copper orange color that naturally pours with the look of a nitrogen infused beer , yet only produces about a 1.5 finger head .  12oz bottle poured into a shaped pint glass . after the initial pour , hopback amber looked exactly as a beer should . the smell and taste were very good , with a crisp grapefruity essence . hopback amber is refreshing and clean , with a solid , but short-lived hops presence that is as fleeting on the tongue as its good looks were in the glass . hopback amber could be a go-to hot weather , or post-workout , beer for hop heads . it was easy to drink and had me imagining i was sitting at a tavern 's outside deck on a lazy , sunny july day .

poured into sam adams ' lager glass ; head was pronounced , but short lived ( note : i had sampled a beer previously in this glass but rinsed ) ; color was dark brown , with a hint of charcoal gray ; the smell was somewhat sour and , frankly , not appetizing ; the taste reminded me of tobacco , i.e .  m : really carbonated , even a bit much . thin body otherwise , however -- just a bit more oomph here and this would be epic .

poured from a 12oz brown bottle into a clear pint glass a : clear honey-gold color with medium-thick off-white head and ample lace . a very pretty beer .  mouthfeel : on the light side of medium with a crisp finish . it is a touch too thin imho . with the malt being so delicous , i want a bit more body to compliment it .

pours a wonderfully deep mahogany with a two finger tan head that leaves impeccable sheets of lacing to the very end .  body was a smidgen thin , but it held the 8 % back quite well , i knew it was more that 5 % , but thats what i perceived from this great brew .

fresh floral and citrus nose , the smell is fantastic in fact .  i 'm 90 % sure this is the same beer as their `` gretchen 's gold '' , which is really what i 'll be reviewing . the bottled version leaves much to be desired vs. on draught . i 've not tasted such a difference between tap and bottle in any other beer . extremely refreshing and drinkable , pleasant sweet malt w/ barely discernable hops for structure . scant head . overall a great beer in its style , with no real flaws . if you can get it on tap , it 's well worth it .
smells incredible , good enough to eat !  the mouthfeel is a little lighter and more carbonated then i am looking for in the imperial stout category .
gorgeous . thin white head does n't stay around very long .  a little watery at the end .

pours yields a hazy light golden brew with a substantial head of thick white foam with really fantastic retention and a lot of lacing as it goes down .  mouthfeel was average -- no bad bite , but not much body either .
pours dark black with small off white head .  m - the pumpkin gives this beer a slick mouthfeel , and it could use a bit more carbonation , too .
a - if looks could kill ... . very inviting .  light body , fizzy carbonation , as expected . basic adjuncts , some sweetness and a light touch of skunk .

a 22 oz bottle picked up while in illinois this one pours a black body and medium tan head . a really nice head with lacing and very foamy .  the only place that is lacking is the body is a little watery .

it descended at a visiably appreciable rate , but the once billowing cloud was well documented by the labyrinths of foam left on the glass . a thick heady atoll sits in my glass ' center floral , grassy , currant hop aromas spring from the excited carbonation .  a bit fizzy , thinner mouthfeel -but this contributes to the drinkability of the beer .

the beer erupted from the 12 ounce brown bottle a piceous color , the head bunyanesque in size , spumescent in texture and a nice chocolate brown color , after several weeks , it evaporate and the resultant lace formed a nice sticky sheet to conceal the glass .  m- medium body , definitely unfiltered .

smell is very enjoyable , lots of thick fruitiness and burnt sugar , with a stab of wine-like alcohol . unexpectedly complex , with a great grape and olive finish .  mouthfeel : a ton of carbonation gave this beer a very fuzzy feel to it .

very balanced . really great . most pumpkin ales smell like pumpkin and spice , this one spells like a baked pie . a more than solid representation of the style , though the taste was a slight light down after the amazing aroma .  oooh not so happy with this so very unfortunately . diaceytl ( sic ? ) characeristics brusquley intrude . me no likey . i 'm certain that there are other good qualities to this brew , but for me the butterscotch stuff supecedes . good bye .

quite nice , a very good aroma for the style ( belgian pale ) . my hopes really got high upon smelling this one , i thought i was in for a very pleasant surprise .  there is a slight floral hop scent to go along with the malt aroma that you would expect from a beer this dark . this is a flavorful lager . it 's malty without being sweet and there is just enough hoppyness to leave a bite on the tongue .
mostly clear golden amber body . two fingers of thick , whipped , light beige head . good lacing .  overall feel is good enough , but was a bit thin .
it had a great smell and a smooth taste .  body is thinner than expected on the palate , and the uppity carbonation level does n't help .

i do n't mean pale , i 've seen paler ipas ( sweetwater ipa is more yellow and less red ) , just thin . the aroma is heavenly . big fruity hops , a bit of sweetness , a very aromatic beer . it would have been nice if the juiciness had carried through from the aroma , but it did n't . the malt is seriously lacking . it 's not that the hops are really overpowering , it 's just the malt backbone is n't there to hold it up . if the flavor was as good as the appearance and aroma this would be an incredible beer . still not bad though .  mouthfeel is thin and becomes slightly tannic at the finish .
great smell , unlike other lagers . pretty awesome infact .  m- medium body , slightly carbonated , has a bit of creaminess to it .

a : deep amber beer with two fingers of pale cappucino head which creates caters as it settles s : not much here , some citrus hops are detected t : bready malt up front , unexpectedly sweet , eventually the hops come through though a small amount m : sweeter than expected , low carbonation d : good drinkability , could do with more hops o : an average beer , had this a little warmer than preferred , but not bad .  mouthfeel : just barely medium-bodied .

half the glass is huge , frothy , rocky head . nice !  surprisingly light in the mouth , and very drinkable , but as i have been rereading some of my reviews lately , i think everything is drinkable , it seems that i would almost always take another .

drank from a bottle into my rodenbach tulip , bottled last week of january 2011 ... looks great , a super dark dark with amber , shiny . the head is tope , great retention and lacing ... the aroma is equally nice , very hoppy ( light car pissyness and a hint of citrus ) but balanced with some spicy rye notes .  m : fairly light , slick body with a low amount of spiky carbonation . mediocre .

i really like this scent , it has a very strong oak and bourbon presence with the malts giving it a strong backbone . taste on the other hand , lacks behind the wonderful scent . starts watery with some sweet sugars , oak and coffee . this beer had a lot going for it initially , a nice appearance and great aroma . at first i was pleased with the taste , but the finish and lingering flavors almost ruined the beer for me .  m : medium body and carbonation . it is a little sticky . some sharpness on my tongue as i swallow .
a : looks absolutely fantastic .  mouthfeel : it was a very light beer .

a : pours a very dark amber , can barely see through it , thick white head , copious lacing around glass s : loads of aromatic hops in the piney variety , some citrus , little to no malt presence ( dominated by these delicious smelling hops ) . this has an excellent smell ! t : taste pretty much matches nose , a walloping of piney hops with a little more depth than what i could smell . has a nice spicieness to it .  the body is light and the carbonation is very high .
s- one of the best smelling beers i 've come across .  m : medium-little body , ok carbonation .

n- massive fruity hops , big fresh centennial and cascade pellets , fresh grapefruit , pineapple , fresh pine , caramel . really just a super dank hop nose . t- astringent , dry , resinous , loads of nutty bitterness piling on . sort of one dimensional .  m : medium but complex body with minimal carbonation .

the first beer to be poured into my brand new franziskaner weizen glass . the white foam lays atop a gorgeous , hazy organic unfiltered apple juice-colored body . ok lacing , good retention .  the nose is malty and flowery ( like clover honey ) , but also a bit resinous as well . the flavor is not as sweet as the nose might lead you to think- dry malt and an odd spicyness- like some kind of combination of cinnamon , wood , and earth . this ancient traditional beer is another of those brews with a history - it 's been brewed in scotland for 4000 years . you wo n't think of beer as just a common drink after exposing yourself to this . well worth the experience , it is as complex as any wine you might try .
great big froth of beige over basic bubbly copper .  this beer is exceptionally thin in the mouth however .
this is a beautiful looking beer .  m : a bit thin , but still decent .

a bit of citrus and sweet caramel mixed in only makes this better . top notch !  mouthfeel -- medium-light in body with prickly carbonation . slightly gentler carbonation would have been preferable , but a twirl or two dozen remedies the issue .
this stout poured out of the bottle with a deep black body and a nice creamy looking head .  a little thin in the body for my taste , and a bit low in carbonation .
poured into a tulip pours a beautiful clear deep amber with two fingers of thick , creamy head ( almost like foam on a root beer float ) .  mouthfeel and carbonation are both slightly low .

big three fingers of off-white head , fading to a thick cap with great retention and maybe slightly patchy lacing . looks more like a nice stout than a bsda or black ipa .  tart up front , with ample carbonation clinging to bitter noble hops . mouthfeel is medium bodied with a lingering puckering finish . a decent overall tripel here .

notes from 08/25/2010 : 12 oz can at 45 degrees into a stone irs tulip . a : it pours a luscious golden-orange color with a fluffy finger of off-white head that holds and laces well .  medium-bodied rather than thick .
smells great . t-does n't live up to the nose , but still solid .  mouthfeel was of mouthful of hand-picked lickers .
real good retention and lacing .  the mouthfeel was much lighter than expected with a slight buttery feel .

appearance : the beer poured a nice 3 finger chocolate colored head . also , beer is pitch black with no clarity and no signs of carbonation . the head of beer has not come down yet and will have to say the retention is fantastic and lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is pretty standard , with some syrupy texture from the malts .

ridiculously amazing nose of white wine , oak , ripe pear , white pepper , and earthy brett . really special . getting a ton of that chardonnay character in the taste , lots of ripe melon and pear , oak , white grapes , and honey with a touch of brett and more saison flavors of white pepper , yeast , and lemon peel . not quite as epic as the nose , but still very unique and delicious . mouthfeel is crisp , with a medium body , sharp , `` spritzy '' carbonation , and a nicely dry finish . overall an excellent saison , and easily one of the most memorable examples of the style i 've ever had !  man talk about pleasantly surprised ... after the last two i wasnt expecting much from this random brew ... glad i picked the best for last ... pour couldnt get much better with a great levitating head and awesome lacing ... nice floral hop aroma , slight alcohol tone not obnoxious at all ... taste is almost all nutty malt , somewhat dry ... alcohol is amazingly well hidden ... one of the easiest drinking malt liquors ive ever had ... too bad the turks got it right before we did ... keep in mind that this four is rated in accordance to other euro strong lagers/malt liquors ... cheers !

s : bouquet is well presented and complex . pine , citrus and flower all come through well . d : a decent dipa , but definitely has room for improvemet . the hops were a little clashing as well . i liked it overall , but if this one is to be brewed again i would hope that they tweak it a little .  also a bit of a watery feel .
pours a super sexy , rust brown with great white lacing and a 1/2 inch head .  m-to me its a little thin to carry around this level of hops .

this produced a a half a finger of dark tan head of tiny and tightly packed bubbles . the head dissipated quickly leaving virtually no lacing . a - a perfect dark , dark brown .  m - sticky for a bock with low levels of carbonation .

black with a very thick and creamy head that 's sticking a quarter inch out of the top of the glass and is n't going anywhere .  a bit thin in the mouthfeel but nothing off-putting .

a- pours a hazy , luminescent orange liquid with a thick and craggy white head that has great retention .  the mouthfeel is ... well ... ok ... a little bit of an after taste and the alcohol is apparent ... the beer is absolutely worth a try ...

beautiful amber/red color and nice thick white head . impressive retention and lacing .  it does feel a little thin in your mouth , but it smells exactly what it 's name says : a cocoa porter . the beer tastes like chocolate milk made with nesquick or ovalteen or anything other chocolate powder brand with a mild , beer after-taste .

gorgeous clear and deep mahogany oak pour , topped by a massive ivory head . really liked the sediment goodies at the end of the bottle .  m : carbonation comes on unexpectedly crisp , but it drinks smoothly .

) poured into a pint glass pitch black with two fingers of thick , dark tan/grey head that lingers like light pancake batter and laces nicely - if i did n't know better , i 'd think it was a solid stout so far .  mouthfeel : a bit loose , i expected it to be a bit thicker . carbonation is spot on though .

the beer poured deep golden and slightly hazy , topped by a dense , off-white head . excellent lacing remained on the glass .  mouthfeel was disappointingly thin and watery with a medium amount of carbonation .
appearance : great looking dark lager with gorgeous dark hue , nice lacing , and medium carbonation .  m : slightly watery , but forgivable considering its low alcohol content .

black with cocoa-brown highlights and a very good head for the abv .  bottle thanks to scoobydank referral ! blackberry is heavy on the nose . very nice . blackberry hard on the front , then a nice porter , then blackberry hard on the finish . i recommend this one , try it , for the price , you cant go wrong . honestly nothing more i can say about it . worth it , but not amazing .

black , very black kind of like used motor oil , did'nt have much goin on for the people that like to smell em ( but i havent caught on to that yet , still tryin ) i did enjoy the taste , at times it was like burnt coffee , kind of earthy-metallic but very smooth , i think two 12oz would be just about right ( ill know for sure in bout 10min ) p.s .  weakest aspect of this beer is the body , which is a bit on the thin side , with light carbonation .

s : classic sculpin nose , mango and apricots , very tropical and distinct . there is some heat on the back end from the chiles , but nothing that grabbed me , nothing that screamed habanero . still a solid effort .  m - even , with a slight bitter aftertaste .

from the second i cracked open the cap , the room filled with the sent of vanilla , as far as smell goes this the best smeling beer ever ! the tast is good but not as good as i had hoped this one is sweet with a fair vanilla kiss and a carmalised malt flavor . i think it might be the hop aftertaste on this one , i would rather have this one finish sweet .  mouthfeel was n't terrible , with the nice carbonation going on it actually kinda danced on the tongue .
it poured a surprisingly beautiful cloudy red , i would describe it like a strawberry color . good carbonation and a nice pink tinted white 1/2 inch head .  m - very light for a stout .
smell is fantastic ... filled w/ piney hops w/ a whiff of cotton candy .  mouthfeel has definitely lost some over the years unfortunately , its almost still and lacks life .

a : initially pours a very creamy orange , but that clears up instantly to reveal a sparkling , well carbonated , orange/gold beer with a two finger fully off white head . there 's a little haze , but the head is so beautiful and that balances it out .  it 's a bit thin in the mouth .
a - thick , light brown head that stays forever . opaque black except for a tint of dark ruby on the edges .  medium mouth feel , with decent drinkablity
terrific retention , sticky lace . great looking beer .  medium-light body with moderately-high carbonation . good but a bit astringent and tannic .

pours a slightly hazy reddish amber with a thick and frothy cream-colored head . retention is excellent and loads of fluffy/sticky lacing is left behind .  the carbonation is medium strong ; the few medium sized bubbles are fresh . the liquid is semi-smooth . a lager with lots of off flavours .

s : the aromas of sweet vanilla and caramel hit you right when you open the bottle . amazing to say the least . not much of a hoppy aroma . smells like a great dessert beer .  a nice malty finish mouthfeel is a crisp and clean , quite a bit of carbonation , somewhat dry and sticky aftertaste . a bit more body would have made it excellent for it was a bit light a very drinkable beer .

a - cloudy ( i know this from the pour-ing ) , extremely dark , opaque brown . head is huge , dense and creamy .  mouthfeel : carbonation is average . body is unfortunately a little thin , contrary to what your taste buds are telling you .
pours a golden color with great clarity and a huge white head .  m- light body and good carbonation , nothing stellar here .
very sweet malty smell . there is a spicy sweet combintation in play in this beer with a slight astringency about it .  m : moderate body , mild carbonation .

the beer looks great . deep red and oranges with a sticky off white head .  i poured this guinness into my tumbler at 45 degrees . the beer was very black and bore out a big tan head . the beer smells like a guinness as it should . the taste was big molasses but the brew had a bit of a dry finish . i like the beer and will buy again .

a : black as night , with no light passing through . great retention on this baby .  s. rich brown sugar , molasses and smoke t. quite complex with molasses , roasted malt , smoke , brown sugar , cinnamon and clove in the front with a touch of hops in the back m. surprisingly clean , with lingering malt behind medium carbonation d. very drinkable for anyone who likes malt i first tried this beer at a local liquor store 's beer tasting . this is a great example of a fall seasonal for the relaxed craft drinker .

2010 bottles on the shelves now are probably not worth buying at $ 9- $ 10/pop unless you have a lot of patience and extra space in your cellar ... i did have the fortune of trying a version of this beer at new beer distributors a few months back in december that was `` randalled '' through coffee beans that had been soaked in bourbon .  the beer poured into the glass to reveal a nice copper color . the aroma was slightly bready with a mild hop character . the taste was mildly malty at first then gave way to a nice hoppy dryness in the finish . the is a nice quaffable beer .

it poured a deep black color with a decent sized head and lacing .  quite an enjoyable beer but in my opinion not as good as rogues other beers . i wish that the mocha flavor was more prominent like kona brewerys pipeline porter . the subtle tones of mocha make this an appealing porter . i 'd recommend this to any porter lover .
pours gold with a reddish tint . big rocky head .  lightly bodied with a lean , but passably dextrinous mouthfeel .

pours a nice brown amber , with huge foamy off-white head that has great retention .  very nice hoppy taste , crisp and clean with a nice malt balance and a great bitter aftertaste . goes down fine , perhaps a bit rough from overcarbonation , but a very well down ipa .

a- pitch black with a nice off white/ cream color head with some lacing s- strong smell of malt , lots and lots of malt t- good some malts with a hint of bitter hops m- lighter bodied than i first expected , almost like a swartzbeir .  mouthfeel : medium bodied and a bit undercarbonated imho .

poured from a 750ml caged bottle , immediately hit with the citrus-y , yeast aroma expected from a saison . immediate taste is lemony and refreshing , very similar to the aroma . lingering taste is sweet , with a pronounced alcoholic bite .  brief bitter finish and mouthfeel was a little watery for the style .

aroma is sweet and spicy , with floral notes and definate coriander and also brown sugar and molasses . very complex nose . first sip reveals a silky smooth body with almost non-existent carbonation . no hint of the abv anywhere , and the beer is extremely drinkable and goes down easily .  m : a little too much carbonation on this one .

pours a sunny straw yellow with a vast , lasting head .  i wonder how this brew would taste on my pancakes , or maybe waffles ? thick and syrupy body , which was expected because its made with maple syrupmaple aromas on the nose , along with molasses , raisins , caramel and of course alcohol . exactly the same can be tasted on the palate , but everything is just taken to the extreme and it not enjoyable at all . i split this with my pop on father 's day , and he agreed that it also , is just to extreme , i could n't imagine drinking the whole bottle myself ...
with a gorgeous amber golden cloudy colour , her lean legs kept calling me back for more . a perfect introduction to the local libations brewed in georgetown wa .  feels like champagne .

the very minimal head reduces to a very thing ring around the glass and this absolutely beautiful white spider web pattern of foam across the middle . this is a damn fine looking beer .  taste : this is a fairly thin-bodied brew , and the carbonation seems a little much . it has a nice malty taste in the middle , but it 's dominated by strong , orange-tasting hops . this is certainly a hoppy beer , but the hops are n't that intense or asskicking .

22oz bottle into a duvel tulip pours a deep almost opaque black with a nice frothy khaki head that lasts and leaves nice lacing on the glass .  the aroma has a touch of stale coffee that then moves to a better defined roasted malt in lager form . the dark malts are great , minus ther adjunt must to it . i ca n't really explain why , but this is one of my , `` right after a hard day of work while you wait for dinner to cook beer . '' easy on the palate and tastes good from the bottle and the glass .
aroma : this smells really delicious . there 's grapefruit , sweet orange , apricots , peaches , and cotton candy sweetness .  somewhat thin and watery mouthfeel .

a tasty beer that looked great in the glass .  this is not a beer for holding onto and chatting this is a beer for downing quick . when it heats up , the taste gets worse . there are alot better australian beers than this .

pours an ominous black with dark brown head that is thick & creamy . simply amazing appearance .  the mouthfeel is a decent medium , a little too much carbonation results in a thinner feel than i would like .

served in a nonic , the 75 min ipa appears with 2 fingers worth of silky , creamy white head . displays a solid amount of retaining power that lasts with a full finger 's worth until the last sip . the lacing on the glassware appears as a webbing just about everywhere it was in contact . the brew itself is a hazed golden orange color .  fairly light body and a slightly watery mouthfeel .

the nose was outstanding . tons of peach and apricot notes . amazingly fragrant and bright . slightly citrusy and a touch floral . the flavor profile was a bit sharper than i anticipated . i love the fact that more and more of these quality nano breweries keep popping up around massachusetts .  mouthfeel was fine . a little thin - i think that a big , thick mouthfeel would accentuate the pumpkin pie-like characteristic that i think they 're going for .
the color is gorgeous ! deep ruby with a rocky off white head .  perhaps just a bit light in the mouthfeel as far as the style goes .
poured a beautiful dark amber with a nice head .  starts creamy , but finishes surprisingly thin , which is more noticeable as the beer warms .

it pours a very impressive , large head - thick and bubbly - giving one the impression they may be about to experience something spectacular . the hops swirl and dance as you pour . excellent lacing down the glass as the head dissipates .  a bit prickly in the mouthfeel , but a nice tripel .

12 oz bottle from my trip out west over christmas app : a wonderful blend of dark amber , ruby , and garnet . fluffy tan head that fades to a nice cap and thick lace .  m - the feel is sharp initially with a chalky and sublime salty finish on the palate .
the rich smoky aroma has strong tones of roast coffee and molasses and just a whisper of unsweetened chocolate , demanding a taste .  light body , wish it were bigger and more creamy .
smell dark malts , a inviting chocolate smell with a beautiful sweetness .  m-moderate carbonation , medium-bodied beer , with a noticeable hoppy dryness .

aroma is sweet , fruity , ( raisins , plums ) malty with a little milk chocolate ( whoppers candy ) . lively mouth-feel . flavor does not quite come together tho . it has a mix of sweet fruits , sourdough bread , bitter citrus pith , but it just doesnt seem to be balanced .  m : a little spritzy and thin for my taste .

lucky me ... the bartender was so cool about the pour erupting with soch a frothy top , he gave me a 2nd on 'da house . poured into a wide mouthed tulip , ruddy amber with a beige inch cap that decreased with spotty coating .  very light and summer-appropriate . could drink several . definitely a solid brew .

hazy dark yellow colour . there is a huge off-white head which lasts and lasts .  carbonation is a little too pronounced .

a : poured a one fingered head while being a beautiful amber with carbonation rising . the carbonation is rising throughout the snifter equally which is rare for carbonation rising and some carbonation even sits at the base of the glass . this also laces beautifully down the glass . this even come in nice and creamy because of its great lasting head .  the mouthfeel is a little crisp but does smooth out .

it pours opaque black with a very generous , long-lasting sticky tan head in my fin du monde glass ( great with stouts i find ) .  m - thin body , or at least thinner than expected . low carbonation .

the beer is unlike anything else available ; and they introduced the nitrogen pour to the world . people find it to be heavy , thick , rich and strong when in fact it is light , thin and low in alcohol . of course , it does have a certain mouthfeel from the nitro head , and it is roasty . the u.s. version is pasteurized and has an alcohol content of 4.2 % by volume ( budweiser is now 5 % in most states ) .  smells very nutty with mild chocolate roast . the beer fairly sweet tasting with the nuttiness coming through . cabonation is a bit higher than i would like , but other than that it is a very good brown ale .

a - crisp , brilliant clarity . bright orange with hints of red . head is initially thick then fades to a persistent thin layer with gobs of lacing on the glass .  the mouthfeel is not a complex one and is rather unbalanced and nondescript .

aroma is exquisite - spices , yeast , malt , fruit , herbs , in an exotic blend that is beguiling . flavor 's not as intriguing as the nose , but still pretty good . reminds me of a good saison .  typical mouthfeel for a lager i guess , although i do n't know a lot about what this style should be like .

very interesting smell , cherries left in a glass of rum for several hours & sprinkled with sweet malt dust . very nice . black tot mixes genres with the abandon of a dj just discovering the turntable in his parent 's basement . very interesting , & good , beer .  m- much too thin for the style and something this big .

the head on this makes the appearance , a awesome tope head with great retention and lacing that coats the glass the whole drinking experience top to bottom ... the aroma is like a malty ipa , lots of caramel , with grass wet hops , its really appetizing ... taste is grass hops that have a fresh bite which is nice , maybe that bite is the rye .  mouthfeel was a bit thin , pretty amazing for a beer of this gravity , making this dangerously drinkable .
appearance - super pale straw body .  somewhat thin in it 's mouthfeel although a good creaminess creeps up toward the end .

a : pours a beautiful deep mahogany color . a large creamy beige head forms and gently recedes and leaves sticky lace down the glass .  a - poured a black color with a tan head that leaves lacing behind s - is of roasted malt vanilla and some smoke t - follows the nose for the most part the oak gives nice hints of vanilla and the smoked malt seems more present than the regular bottled version which is n't bad to me m - this beer has a thin body with medium carbonation to it d - this oaked version was a very good beer but i 'm still disappointed with the body definitely worth grabbing a pint of if you ever hear about it being tapped

definitely the best looking of the three with a nice yellow/orangey color , cloudy with tasty yeasties .  medium carbonation and a slight astringency .

rocky , 1cm offwhite head capping a rich amber-brown body . good retention .  wow , i enjoyed the flavor of this beer , the hops are more present in the aroma than the taste , maybe showing up in the extremely dry mouthfeel though . not exactly full bodied , a little light compared to the dark lords we were drinking prior to this , but still it matches the flavors in an appealing way .

light head , soft , beautiful reddish copper brown .  mouthfeel is a letdown - it may just be this bottle but the carbonation is too weak . only have one of these 750ml bottles as it 's imported and a special occasion but i 'd be keen to have another one , if only to compare the carbonation .
s : beautiful - huge fan of coffee 's , so this did not disappoint . espresso , roasted coffee beans , just full-on coffee .  m - high carbonation , but a little watery .

the appearance is amazing .. lots of bubbles on the side of glass when poured , a very strong color orange and hardly no foam on top .  mf is a bit lacking , thin , though creamy .
looks beautiful in a trappist glass . after the bubbles settle , it looks like chocolate milk with reddish edges .  the mouthfeel was slightly thinner than expected .

pours a crystal-clear bright golden , with holy-shit levels of turbulent carbonation that makes the head climb out of the glass . it maintains a tight , bone-white head throughout and leaves decent lacing as i go .  m : mouthfeel was a little thin for the style .

excellent looking beer .  like other ommegang brews , too carbonated , which detracts from what would be a nice heavy feel . nice balance makes for very good drinkability ; biggest knock from me is the excessively fizzy feel .
aromas were strong with sweet grains flavors and an earthy tone .  mouthfeel is okay , but needs to be either thicker or creamier to work with the taste -- as is , it 's just a tad watery .

s : this has the most interesting tobacco note i 've found in a beer yet . its the appealing mustiness of well used pipe with accents of cocoa and cherry playing beautifully off of it . the tobacco is here , just as interesting and as appealing , but the tart , slightly funky cherry is more prominent . d : while i absolutely loved the tobacco i found , i do n't think this was quite what they had in mind .  mouthfeel : has a fair body , but nothing out of the ordinary .

pours a pitch black color with a beautiful brown head into my glass . definitely the color of the style . roasted malt greets the nose followed by grassy hops that do n't jump out too much in the nose .  m : pretty thin and not too lively .

on pouring this looks like it 's gon na be good , dark brown-black with a tan milk chocolate color of foam , thick frothy foam too .  it lingers really well on the tongue , very good aftertaste . the mouthfeel is meh , as it 's a little thin .

a : pours a fantastic golden-orange . slightly opaque , with a voluminous yellow head . nice retention , and great lacing . phenomenal .  mouthfeel is slightly thin , with lower carbonation , not bad .

'' i was in the mood for a light , white ale - and this beer definitely delivered . it was crisp and refreshing . taste was tart and light , a little sour , but well balanced . i 'd have this beer again , and again , and again..

has outstanding appearance for a lager .  after several sips i finished the taster and got a bottle of water to cleanse the palate . the body was average for a wit , but the hops made this sloppy mess nearly undrinkable .

poured into a snifter , the brew appears black in color with the faintest line of clarity and brown around the edges . a dark brown finger of head appears and as it slowly recedes , leaves spots and a webbing pattern of lace . a swirl revives a full finger worth of dark brown head .  m : the body is medium and the carbonation is low to medium i suppose .
beautiful copper/orange body with a slight haze topped with a thick , dense , long lasting head . looks beautiful , tastes good , drinks easy .  mouthfeel : medium carbonation .

the color and appearance of this ale is perfect ! it 's a deep dark chocolate brown w/ a thick dark tan head .  body a bit light and bubbly .
a : i loved the appearance of this beer it had a yellow murky tint .  the mouthfeel is clean and crisp , with less body than i 'd hoped for .
poured dark dark brown with a brown head .  mouthfeel is medium to full-bodied .

hop haze and alcohol feet are evident . the aroma is a good one , with predominant citrus and slight bitterness , with a nice malty , caramel aroma .  m - well balanced , but thin and slightly sweet . was hoping for a medium to full-bodied saison .

lacing is superb but head retention is merely `` well above average . '' color is an opaque blackness that turns a reddish brown only when held up to the brightest lights at the thinnest portion of your glass .  m : too thin and unsustained to be great .

amazing aroma ! there is some type of wood smell in there , as if aged in a barrel . reminiscent of a belgian strong ale , with the spices and the alcohol content . a beautiful and different beer drinking experience . warms my belleh .  well , what can i say . this is definantly the most unique beer i have ever tried . this beer would make a wonderful cooking beer but for drinking it is possibly one of the worst i have ever tasted . the smell and flavour are just not something i want to drink . very hickory smoked ham . used to flavour a chili it would be wonderful , but like i said , as a drink the nastiest thing in the world . literally like drinking smoked ham .

a deep ruby red with a really dense and creamy light-brown head , this beer is quite gorgeous . with nice , red highlights , this is really a beautiful beer .  mouthfeel is a bit sticky and the flavors stick around for a bit after swallowing .

a- perfect . deep ominous black body with thick creamy dark tan head . the head retention is excellent and a coating of lacing is left all the way down the glass .  smooth and sweet , this is pretty nice . carbonation is a bit low , even for my liking .

alaskan amber i recently drank on tap in idaho . the apperance of this beer is very dark , almost cherry wood looking with a foamy cream head . a very drinkable beer , not to thick and not to light .  m- this beer is very carbonated and somewhat thin , very refreshing .

bottle , served in a wine glass . hazy pastel orange , champagne streams of carbonation . creamy whipped meringue foam that lasts forever , leaving impressive irregular peaks and crags that rise above the rim of the glass .  m : medium , but thicker than expected , this is one of my first lambics , but it really steps up to the plate and is a home run .

it is a big bold german style hefe with a wonderous banana aroma mixed with what i really believe to be brett . now , i know this is not really true to style at all but this smelled like heaven -- all funky et all . the flavor was definately a bit of a let down , as the brett character was not as prevelant , but i could see that it was still there .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied and slightly syrupy . minimal carbonation .

poured a massive light custard yellow head which lasted longest i think i 've ever seen ( almost a merengue ) .  its a huge beer , but the mouthfeel isnt as thick as i would like or expect . good levels of carbonation , and they did a great job of hiding the alcohol .

50cl bottle from system in lund sweden a - beautiful ! very dark indeed . head is a nice chocolate color .  m : sticky and fairly thick , dry , slightly dry , prickly carbonation , hint of warm alcohol , just a little too syrupy for my taste .
( a ) - pours almost pitch black with a large light brown head that slowly dissipated to a solid 1-finger . plenty of lacing present .  mouthfeel : medium body , ok carbonation . pretty average .
visually this beer is flawless . sticky cement lacing .  feels a bit thin , low-medium body and medium carbonation .
it stays forever and looks beautiful like a solid entity .  102 ibu ... tastes sweet , like honey and ginger ale with a touch of malt . little too syrupy to be super refreshing but still awesome .

great looking ipa .  t & m : this is a well rounded stout . nicely carbonated , well balanced with a nice roasted bitterness ( but not offensively so ) and sweetness from the malted oats . feels a little on the `` watery '' side for a stout though .
smell - very malty . chocolate and a slight hint of light roasted coffee .  mouthfeel - the only downside imo is that it has a dry finish and leaves the pallet thirsty .

amazing , huge , fluffy , foamy nut colored head is sculpted and precariously teetering well out of the rim of the glass . damn thats sexy . well crap .  m/d : medium bodied , but seemed a little thin and very easy to drink .
this is one beautiful looking beer . it is a slow pour , due to the vast amounts of light tan head that is created .  m : the mouthfeel is okay but feels a little thin , especially for a dipa .
really interesting and unique smelling . tastes similar , with grapefruit and spice/grain up front , pine , and again kind of a honey and malt sweetness .  it feels pretty average for this style .

smells wonderfully of grapefruit , hemp and pine notes with some herbal and alcohol notes .  however , the body is a little thin , with a slighlty soapy feel .
