a : golden appearance that pours 50/50 liquid and foam . i rated this 5 on appearance because this beer has the best head on a beer that i 've seen . it is rocky and tightly beaded , leaving a lace as it slowly recedes .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with sharp carbonation .

a : pour is a hazy light orange , almost like a creamsicle . 3 inches of frothy head sinks slowly back into the beer .  as a williamsburg native , and dark beer fan , i was severly disappointed with this porter . it could have been that the six pack was skunky , i guess . nonetheless , a big disappointment . if one could imagine a porter that is too sweet , this would fit into that category . baltika is also a sweeter porter , but only has a hint . this beer is blatantly sweet .

thanks to mer who imported this from italy ( hey i was hoping there would be italian on the bottle , but oh well ) ... appearance : i sampled this in a chalice ( not a chimay chalice however ) , which effects the color a bit ... the beer was slightly cloudy and blood red , bordering on brown . head was about an inch thick on top , white and megenguey ( alright , do n't know how else to describe it , but it stayed above the top of the glass without spilling over like a merengue pie ) .  the flavor is lightly sweet thought , with some wheat towards the beginning , going to some hops , and a light sweet finish . for me , a pretty good summer session brew .
this beer pours a very large light tan head with great retention and amazing lacing .  mf- a bit thin . leaves a good feeling in the mouth after you are finished . carbonation a bit high .

very clean and very aromatic . taste : the tropical fruit hop flavor really is the main note in the flavor profile . overall , a nice , aromatic ipa with good tropical fruit notes .  there is a lack of head or carbonation , the body is very cloudy with a chunky suspension . the flavor is also adversely affected , the malt tastes raw and grainy , and it masks whatever this beer is supposed to taste like . i will be pouring this bottle out , i am hoping that this is an exception , not the rule from this beer .
lots of full bodied lovely lacing when stirred .  m - medium to light body .

a : it pours a completely opaque black color with two fingers of white nitro froth that laces incredibly well .  very dark with maybe a hint of red if you hold it up to the light . a little flat so the mouthfeel is not as good .

among the best smelling brews ive experienced . t : flavor not as exquisite as the nose but still tight . i enjoy the bitterness of this imp stout matched with the deeply roasted malt . not the best tasting ris but the best aromas in my opinion .  on the downside the mouthfeel was much fizzier than one would expect ... very thin , too .

it started out well pouring with a clear rich amber color and a nice thick head .  the mouthfeel is nothing exceptional but it is also not bad . it is a bit fizzy but this does n't offset the flavors .
pours a light copper/gold with a big creamy off-white head .  the mouthfeel is just average .
very interesting . taste in line with the nose , with the licorice even more asseritve upfront in the palate .  the body is a little thin for my likes .

the pils hops are there , of course , and quite nice , but much more complex and engaging than the norm . drinkability : while not a great pils , the monster nose makes it interesting enough to recommend .  m - maybe a little on the thin side for me -- the carbonation is higher than i 'm used to .

the aroma is phenomenal , the taste backs off just a bit . there is an earthiness , from the garden of eden , perhaps ?  the disappointing : wow , what a highly carbonated brew , almost champaign in the fizziness .

samuel adams latitude 48 ipa is dark and gorgeous , earthy , and thin . it poured dark copper with a massive tan head .  ( 4 ) m : thin with hi carb ( a little too hi ) and a dry finish . would like a little more body or a little less carb to make this a little more palatable .

the smell of this beer is excelent , smells like coffe flavored chocolate and caramel , but the taste is quite dissapointing , the carbonation hides most of it , i only got a little bit of caramel there .  m - uberchewy , sweet . med-light carbonation .

one pint swing-top bottle & gt ; dimpled mug this is a deep , darl mahogony brown color with a rather impressive 3 '' towering khaki colored head that is pillowy with huge clumpiness , very slow retention with plenety of foam everywhere .  body is full with smooth carbonation , but a bit on the low side .
a - it 's damn hot and muggy here right now , and the bright golden body and thick , fluffy white head 'atop this beer looks really damn good .  m : nothing special .

i wanted so much to love this beer . yeti , oaked yeti , and the phenomenal espresso oaked yeti are heavenly ... but due to some unfortunate choices by great divide this beer will go down as a novelty not to be reproduced . the aroma of this beer and the appearance lead you to believe that this is going to be another great yeti , but the taste and mouth feel ruin the beer . there are subtle notes of the chocolate that hint to what this could have been , but alas they ruined it by unbalancing everything terribly by making this a strange pepper brew .  overall quite mouthfilling , cakey , dangerously smooth and rounded . the beer takes a bit of a down turn towards the end as the flavors fizzle a bit and the beer seems to thin out and go a bit watery . mouthfeel , while not ever being truly creamy , comes close with real soft and smooth carbonation .

s : fresh crushed raspberries , sweet and fragrant . does n't smell like beer at all .  the mouth is fairly thick ( for a lower abv lager , that is ) , and the carbonation is too high , unless poured a little hard .

pours out with a cloudy yellow body and a huge white pillowy head of foam . the head breaks down slowly leaving a mountain of foam in the middle and covering the entire glass .  m - thin and a little astringent , but it is very refreshing apart from that .

s- this beer smells of tart cherries and a hint of musty basement and a soft oak note .  i am almost positive this is living under the assumed name of `` doc mason 's ryepa '' at solana beach . aroma is rye , caramel malt , and hops . nice hop bite up front with a smoother rye and caramel back . acidic and alcoholic finish .

pungent candied grapefruit with sharper notes of lemon zest , bolstered with stately light caramel malt . simcoe dry hop character overwhelms , agreeably so . tepid clementine hints provide a softer citrus character .  m : on the lighter side .
huge 3 finger head with lines , legs and lace galore .  the mouthfeel is atypical for a saison . it 's a little heavier and not as carbonated as is typical of the style .

a - the darkest brown possible without being black . head is 1.5 fingers with a beautiful dark tan color that leaves some nice lacing as the brew is consumed .  i 'm sorry guys but another swing and a miss . beer aggressively foamed out the bottle immediately on opening , after sitting in the refigerator for two days , so no mistakes on my part there . the sourness overwhelms any good qualities which are there , lying underneath but truly irrelevent . cigar city is a great brewery with great potential but lets get it together guys . do not put these beers on the shelf when they are clearly sub-par . cheers everybody- it 's only beer . i expect great things from this brewery but let 's please enact some quality control .
awesome retention and structure . the beer was a very dark/murky brown color that looked like rugged/worn leather .  mouthfeel : feels slightly carbonated and thicker than water on the tongue .
very english in appearance , burnished copper tending towards shades of yellow . creamy , sustained eggshell head with lovely lacing .  medium thin body .

huge , frothy head .  the drink was citrusy at the front , with a floral spicy taste towards the middle with a subtle hop kick at the end . i found this beer to be very interesting and enjoyable . it would make a good stand alone , or a good session beer .

rather transparent and light copper in color . good layer of retention and thick lacing .  taste was somewhat bitter , and more of the hops , with alcohol becoming more evident in both the aroma and taste at mid-glass . finish was slightly bitter aftertaste , but mostly smooth and a bit dry .

s-the smell of this beer is amazing ! having had perseguidor 3 , i would say this is the only trait that is better in 4 . insanely complex nose , smells of wood , funk , dried fruit , chestnuts and roasted malt . truely exceptional . there is virtually no stout flavor , i tastes similar to an old bruin , but thiner and less acidic , a sipper to be sure do to the tartness , but very tasty . d-another great offering in this series , captain ron is a master at blending his styles .  m-not very carbonated , lighter body than expected but too light in between the medium .

there are some good things going on here ; the aroma is quite nice , but the flavor comes across as a little rough and it just does n't have enough complexity to justify the huge alcohol content .  m : one of the few beers where carbonation is probably a bit too strong and covers up some of the wonderful and interesting flavors going on here .

sat on my table next to the bottle , the scene looked like the picture you would see on an advertising board . it looks so good , what a pity it does n't live up to the promise its image paints .  m - medium to light bodied . it 's just thinner than i expected .

a - pours a brilliant clear amber with an off-white moundy head that takes it 's time going down . provides beautiful sheets of lacing .  i had this on tap at victory brewing a - a very pale golden with good clarity and small snowy head with small bead , little lacing collects s - the smell is yeasty , with subtle sweet malt and mild floral hops m - the feel is thin , but apropos to style w/ light malt texture sweet herbal hop feel and kind of watery finish t - the flavor is crisp , clean and sweet w/ floral hops not really adding any contrast in the way of bitterness .
i poured this one in a pint glass and was impressed by the large head .  mouthfeel : a little thin ; carbonation too .

it was a clear dark honey color with lots of carb streams and great lacing . it had a massive white head that took forever to whittle down to a constant 1/4 '' foam .  if only the texture was less paper thin and more like cardboard .
appearance : a gorgeously intense brown/amber color with a tremendously dense tan head that lasts and lasts and lasts .  m : mouthfeel is thin , crisp , but a little watery .

smell : this beer has a very sweet and fruity aroma . you can also smell some of the malts .  sampled at the paper city brewery on free beer night . i know that this beer was free so i should n't complain about it but there was something wrong with this beer . my guess is this was a bad keg otherwise they brewed it with their dirty gym socks . reflection : i know that this is a harsh review but unless you were there that night and tried it you ca n't understand the horror of this beer .

extraordinarily enjoyable , i 've had double ipa 's that do n't smell this good . not nearly as complex as the smell would indicate .  a beer haiku for you : '' norwegian beer ? yes ! a great ipa option , seek out and find one ! '' my first norwegian [ that 's what she said ] . nice citrus overtones , not too 'hoppish ' , and very drinkable . a rare find , but well worth the money to have another option .
black with a tan nitro-head and a nitro-retention that leaves a literal wall of lace .  it had a medium to light body .

gorgeous though , one of the most visually appealing beers i 've seen .  modest bitterness , warmth . some great foaminess but a bit too much . malty sweetness . this is high calorie beer , the good stuff .

poured a hazy orange amber colour with a thick head that had very good retention . this was a beautiful beer with tons of visual character .  a little grittiness in the texture . m - a little weird and overcarbonated for a porter . it would be better off less carbonated and as creamy as it appears .

a : appears a brilliant clear copper with hues of red , creamy white 1 finger head , little lacing s : the aroma is quite muted , not picking up much more than some sweet malts and a touch of caramel .  for the most part this is quite smooth , although the carbonation is just a tad too harsh to fully appreciate some of the nuanced flavors .

smell- nice aroma that strikes an excellent balance between malt and aroma hops . a nice sweet citrus aroma along with a very nice malt sweetness comes through the nose as well . taste- taste is not as nice as the smell , but it is still quite nice . it has a nice maltiness with a powerful jolt of bittering and flavoring hops ... for a belgian pale ale .  m - my only complaint about this beer , wish it would thicken up a bit . approriate carbonation .

the nose is very complex and rich with lots of deep rich chocolatey malts and spices . some hops too . very sweet from the get go , and reminds me quite a bit of sn bigfoot .  t-coffee up front followed by a grape raisin in the middle and a cocoa powder/unsweetened chocolate finish . m-kind of watery and a bit syrupy , not unpleasant but not great d-alcohol very well hidden , but warming and at 4.50 $ a bomber could be quite dangerous .
amber pour with an effusive white head that left great lacing and never dipped below a substantial film .  light bodied with a crisp carbonation . this beer is pretty damn horrible .

laces magnificantly ; elegant and 2-toned . nose is powerful and intense , coffee , oak , and cocoa , just as it should be . pretty much spot-on . some oak on the finish , and a lot of robust roasty malt in the middle . quite bitter , but not from hops , mostly bitter cocoa ... cellaring would probably do wonders for this . edit : read the label mention of cayenne and it completely clicked . mouthfeel is very , very , very fine carbonation . overall bitter , but not dry nor particularly rich .  roasted aroma with hints of dark ( bittersweet ) chocolate and coffee . could be fuller bodied , a little less on the tounge then expected . different flavors hint you on the first sip , roasted malt , coffee , dark chocolate , hop citrusness . finishes dry with some hop bitterness and a nice aftertaste . another quality brew from the boys and rogue !

s : the aroma is moderate to strong and is a pleasant mlange of toffee , vanilla and oak . t : the initial taste is predominantly toffee and is followed by notes of oak and vanilla .  the mouthfeel is a bit on the thin side for a stout .

smells hoppy , fresh , and fruity , with a slight floral touch . somebody could write a review about the scent . absolutely wonderful fresh tasting with a hoppy bite .  m : a little bit smooth , medium body , medium carbonation , finishes a little bit sticky , like i said before , its more like juice than beer .

pours with a very large , stable , light tan head . good lacing .  i like the way this beer opens up although it ends up tasting a bit thin for the rest of the drink . m- smooth , sticky , but not thick at all .
s - wonderful coffee scents with vanilla and hints of dark chocolate . just a great smelling brew that i could keep my nose in for hours .  m- medium mouthfeel with a bit of fizz .

poured a medium tan head with fine-small bubbles . this was a smooth drinking stout without the super strong coffee taste ; however , i have had better tasting stouts since i have started my rating of beers .  m : lighter body than i would like in this style , kind of like zywiec porter light in this respect .
slightly hazy dark amber with a big very-light-brown head with great r & l .  m- a bit too carbonated for the style in my opinon .

from a nitro filled pint size can ... pours honey golden yellow with typical nitro-style can head . the head is very dense , creamy and leaves belgian lacing all the way down to the end .  a bit of a thin mouthfeel , for a porter .

the aroma is rife with vanilla bean and a fresh , sharp rye spiciness . caramel sugar daddies and liquefied raisinettes make for a sweet touch that plays well off the rye bill . overall , this is delicious stuff .  this brew can feel a little thin , although it 's so tasty that it hardly bothered me .

wow ! this beer is extremely clear and light looking . was n't expecting that ! gorgeous white head that laces awesome . beautiful beer for sure .  was n't crazy about the mouthfeel of this beer though , as i felt it lacked significant carbonation and was a bit thin and lifeless .
a - a huge frothy eternal mocha brown head .  body is a bit thin , probably due to the low alcohol .

a : deep clear red with a fantastic reddish-white head . great looking beer .  the belgian/wheat characteristics are present in the background but also help to make it such a smooth drinking brew m : average mouthfeel with a slight ammount of tongue tingle d : highly drinkable beer with very smooth characteristics but still beautiful tastes overall i absolutly love this beer and it is my mission to spread its wonder to all

a ) glowing amber , 1 '' off-white , pillowy head .  this one strikes me as kind of flat . needs a tad more carbonation and i think it would be leaps better than it is . nice creamy smooth mouthfeel though .

unstoppable hop aroma . grapefruit and citric character invades my nostrils and inflicts a pleasant sting . good double ipa .  this has got a lot of hop bitterness to it , this reminds me a little of hopslam . i did n't really notice the `` hop backbone '' like everyone else has mentioned . like hopslam , this is best drank slowly due to the high abv .

1 finger of soapy tan foam . excellent lacing .  the taste is thick and interesting . its just a tad lacking , leaving this beer to taste like eating hershey 's special dark chocolate powder . this beer coats the tongue well , but the taste is over-powering . i 'm really impressed with the idea here and think this is a good beer .
a - cloudy reddish brown body with a pale tan head that lasts forever at a height of two plus inches .  alas , the mouthfeel is more watery than what one would come to expect from such a taste .
it 's got a beautiful brown body with a fantastic , super long lasting tan head .  mouthfeel : feels like every other kind of amber ale i 've had , not bad .

one of the best looking beers i 've seen . pours a gorgeous dark copper brown ale , with a lovely foam head that sticks around .  bourbon . fizzy enough to make this way too drinkable , and that does a wonderful job of injecting dryness into the sweet , caramelly notes of woody bourbon that are certainly present here . it would be nicer if this beer was a bit thicker and smoother , but i think that would open it up to extreme booziness .

the smell is rich and malty , almost boozy even , with warm notes of caramel and roasted malts . smells like it 's on the verge of being a doppelbock really . the taste is less complex ... the roasted malts dominate big time . a little disappointing after the look and smell of it .  the mouthfeel is thin with a watery texture , and lively carbonation .

on tap at capone 's , served in a pint glass ( 2/7/08 ) a : an intimidatingly dark brown , nearly black , with a thin , foamy , dark beige head that diminishes rather quickly , but leaves a nice trail of sticky lacing throughout .  i just think it 's amazing what ab will do to make a quick buck . hopefully this will quickly go into the grave along with new coke and chrystal pepsi .

the nitro-can helps give the beer a large off-white creamy head that lasts a while . looks great .  carbonation is quite high , body is medium but filled with bubbles , mouthfeel is creamy but slick . very flavorful , but the carbonation ruins the mouthfeel for me .

clear , anthracite ( hehe ) brew with thin rims of chestnut when held to the light . forms a tan head which quickly thins , atop medium-large bubbles with moderate carbonation . solid sheets of lace are left in its wake .  feels a bit thin , where creamier and chewier would 've done the trick .

displays awesome retention , forms a mesa in the middle of the glass and shows off an impressive formation of 3d lace . an awesome appearance and nice aroma save this one from finding the 'c ' range .  mouthfeel is thick , but a little too fizzy .

smell is exactly what it should smell like -- a very malty oktoberfest . tastewise-there is sweetness and caramel and tones of apple too . in fact a little too sour on the finish .  m : very medium-light body and a slightly bitter but almost watery finish .
looks great . an amber-orange color . aggressive pour produced an inch head with a quarter inch lingering for a while , and lacing sticking to the glass all the way down .  it was very astringent .

extrememly frothy and creamy . leaves large chunks and patches behind . a nice lightly clouded golden colored pour .  the mouthfeel is a bit lighter than expected but doesnt detract , and drinkability is excellent for the abv .

appears a pale gold with a nice 2 finger white head that lasts for about a minute . some solid lines of lacing stick to the glass .  little helper is a good beer . defining it is a bit difficult , i would call it a hoppy but light ( er than normal ) red ale . very drinkable . nearly no head . good beer , but the malt flavor is not very interesting , and not pronounced considering the color . but i am a hop fan so that is just fine . all around great , hoppy , and drinkable red . wish rogue made less expensive beer !
populist has a beautiful appearance- a clear and rich copper color , that is regrettably a bit off set by an only average fragrance .  the body on this one is a little too thin .

the aroma here is all hops . very fragrant . i smell lots of floral and earthy hops .  ... big foamy head in to the glass that seems to break its neck to dissipate , but leaves a tiny ring ... is very refreshing and tangy but when it warms it can be a beast , serve cold ! ! .. better than most bmc products and probably somewhat better than miller chill ...
330ml bottle out of my harpoon tulip . the foamy head almost looks like an espresso , with hints of white and mocha .  mouthfeel is light bodied , light carbonation . smooth , but average .

pours black with the prettiest dark tan head that slowly subsides .  there 's a really nice level of hopping in this one , that becomes apparent in the middle and finish . could do with having a bit more body , but its okay as it is .

poured a hazy golden straw with a huge billowy head that turned awesomely rocky and covered about 90 % of the glass with lacing -- pretty cool .  medium carbonation and thin mouthfeel makes this brew very drinkable .

loved the ginger flavor , but not one of the best spiced ales i 've had . definitely worth a try , especially if you like ginger . the beer spells fantastic ! it 's fresh and easy to drink .  mouthfeel is moderate in weight , but this could really use some more carbonation .
this is a great looking beer .  the mouthfeel is a tad thin , lack of malt .

this is interesting , very hoppy and bitter for the body , but clean , tasty , and light at the same time . the aroma is very nice and very german , bready very herbal with a little lemon and a hint of pine .  m : dry , bitter , light/medium bodied , crisp , too much bite from the alcohol .

smell is dominated by lovely oats , backed up by sweet and rich malts . notes of coffee , too . but the really amazing thing about this beer is how much complexity is built into a fairly small package . i ca n't put my name on all the things in the smell , but i can feel them all there .  body is light and mouthfeel is fairly thin and bubbly , with a very clean finish .

poured a gorgeous ruby red , with a cream coloured , fluffy thick head . excellent retention , thick film of foam on the side of the glass , and thick layer of foam atop the beer . one of the best i 've ever seen from a bottle .  m- now this is a little off , the body is a little flabby , and even slightly watery .
can courtesy of sammy : poured a deep dark brown color ale with huge dirty white foamy head with great retention and lacing .  m - smooth and medium/light body . a slightly dry aftertaste .
guinness looks great when poured right . its all black and has a beautiful creamy head which really lasts .  it had a medium feel in my mouth with ok carbonation .

a - dark , dark brown allowing a mere hint of light through at the base of the pint . the head is substantial at two plus inches and maintains some very nice lacing .  feels lighter than expected . reasonable carbonation . perhaps lacking in body but only slightly .

appearance - perfect honey color . a short lived crisp head manages to maintain a thin cap and collar for the whole sampling .  smells like apples , tastes like hops . very tasty . the fragrance certainly did not match the taste , which is a good thing . the apple/apricot scent is strong but would be overpowering to the tongue , the muted apple notes balanced well . i would definitely order this again .

the head is a massive three inches in height , and recedes extremely slowly into thick , sticky lacing that lasts until the beer is gone .  m - thinner than i 'd like , with very fine carbonation . the finish is very dry and short , which contributes to the impression .
smells so good , that i can not wait for it to warm a bit and have to dive right in to taste it .  it was thin and gave a slight hoppiness that did n't last long in the mouth .
when held away from the light it looks completely entirely black . it also pours a nice 2 finger beige head .  the feel is a little to light , almost watery .

a - very full , dark brown . surprisingly translucent when held up to light .  served on tap in the black angus restaurant at the stoudt 's brewery . body is a dark copper color . thick head with excellent lace . the scent is a bit fruity and has elements of apples and hops . a nice balance of sweet malts and bitter hops make up the flavor . alcohol peeks through , which is surprising as this is a relitively low abv ale .
nice mix of buttery malts and slight hop flower to the smell ... gack !  medium to thin in the body . i thought the carbonation seemed a bit to high and lessened my enjoyment of this brew .
it pours a bright , clear lemon color with voluminous white head that billows out and leaves fine lace all over the glass .  m : smooth & a little flat ( thanks to the nitro i 'm sure ) .
s : coffee . lots of it . caramel and chocolate notes round out the aroma .  mouthfeel is rather light with less than medium carbonation .

pours out cloudy bronze and sits murky reddish-amber in the glass with a massive off-white head . fades slowly to a thick coating of foam with nice lacings all around .  it 's union made , can you tell ? there 's little doubt that every canadian past the age of 16 has tried this beer on more than one occasion . when a little older but not wiser , if nothing else comes to mind when the waitress asks , you instinctively order `` just a blue '' . ice cold it 's refreshing , and that is this brew 's raison d'etre . every time . i 've begun the habit of adding a pinch of salt in the glass , which seems to cut the skunk and make this somewhat palatable .

the beer pours a beautiful deep hazy ruby color with a thin white head .  the mouthfeel on a doppelbock is a tricky thing -- too thick and you wo n't be able to drink your half-liter bottle , let alone your full liter mass .

a : slightly hazy orange light copper color with pillowing white head . great head retention especially considering the abv .  the ringwood yeast just tore this up and gave it a slab of butter on top ... m : crisp , but just tastes pretty bad ... d : a pretty bad beer , the ringwood yeast dominates this brew so much that i had to drain pour the rest , too bad .

a beautiful deep red , yet clear .  smells of sweet malt , grains , hops , toasted bread and honey . very weak nose overall . tastes of roasted malt , grains , lemon , citrus hops , caramel , bread and yeast ... a toasty flavor that is not typical for an ipa and more like a lager than an ipa . it 's a bad ipa , not hoppy or like an ipa at all ... a drain pour , as it was tough to finish this beer . bordered on terrible .

a reasonably average american ipa . pours with a nice head , leaving a thick lacing down the entire glass .  appearance : pours a cloudy amber , moderately carbonated with offwhite foam , leaving moderate foamy lacing . smell : hops are floral and sweet , blending well with the strong raspberry undertones . taste : begins tart , with mellow floral hop taste , very light toasty malts which bring forth the hints of raspberry and honeycomb , finishes witha tangy bitterness that allows a slight yet lasting raspberry lingering . drinkability : very delicious small batch by mbc , its well brewed and the subtle notes of the raspberry are not forced , decent abv as well .

11.2oz bottle poured into my darkness glass ... not a gusher but a huge tope head rises about 8 fingers with great retention , decent lacing ... the beer is a medium gold that looks really good ... the front of the aroma is lots of chamomile , not off to a good start in my book .  mouthfeel : feels soft and smooth at first , but the finish is harsh and drying in a way that really detracts from the overall beer .

deep brown brew with a large , beautiful tan head that sticks everywhere , leaving sticky lace all down the glass . this is a beautiful beer .  mouthfeel- a tad thin for the style but still got a nice solid body .

dissipates after about 2 minutes.. smell - orange zest , maybe some banana , coriander , citrus.. has a nice sweet subtle smell , i like it .  m : pretty low carbonation , which is definitely not a problem for the style . the body 's a little thinner than i 'd prefer , though . a nice , smooth mouthfeel to the beer .
mahogany red , crystal clear , big foamy thick head . smell is heavy hops wafting out as soon as the cap is cracked .  the body has a little chalky hard-water feel to it -- like mineraly .
very attractive looking pale ale .  medium to light bodied .

tall creamy head , and yes black as black gets . i have to say this is a great looking stout .  taste was similar , with a slight sourness . maybe it was n't so fresh , but i drank it within a couple days of buying it . did n't taste the alcohol really , but it was still pretty poor i thought , and not what i was hoping or thinking it 'd be .
the smell is just delicious . it 's just so well balanced . not too much or too little of anything .  m : a bit too fizzy upon sipping , and i was looking for a bit more 'heft ' .

coloration is a nice ruddy brown with a healthy 1 '' khaki head which is simply beautiful in appearance . huge and uneven and thick .  mouthfeel : i 've never been a big fan of the body of almost all american porters as they just seem thin , a tad watery , and big on carbonation , and this one does n't break that trend .

s : very floral and some lemon citrus .  mouthfeel is moderately smooth and prickly but ends with a harsh , dry finish with a medium-light body . the finish is intensely dry with an initially harsh potent hop bitterness which smooths out somewhat and lingers on the palate for a long time . a very fine ipa in it 's own right , but not smooth enough or balanced enough to compete with stone ipa or centennial ipa .

what a beauty . the colour is a beautiful transparent copper with a thick creamy looking one inch off-white head .  mouth feel is a little thin at first with too much carbonation for an english style brown .

thanks to sheepnutz for this tasty brew ... it was sampled in a glass chalice appearance : pours a deep amber with an airy off-white head that lasts during the entire session , and laces incredibly down the glass .  light bodied , with very light carbonation tingle on the roof of the mouth , and a slippery feel .

a-light gold color with a thick foamy white head , and a continuous stream of bubbles spiraling up from the center of the bottom of the glass . laces , but real thin/weak .  taste was very pleasant and hard to describe as well . maybe fruity , maybe nutty , not hard to drink at all with a very slight bitter aftertaste . not a hint of the 7 % abv . given the chance i would share it again with someone because of how different it is . i would also like to get my hands on some of the other brews from hitachino nest .

pours verly clear , bright dark orange/amber with a full , firm and thick pure white head . a beautiful pour .  t- hop fruitiness up front , not particularly citrus from the big c hops but just fruity . aftertaste brings up the rear with a hop bitter whollop . m- average for this style , not great but definately not bad .

pours thick with a nice big head that lasts and lasts .  slightly bitter but balnced for a stout , i like the chocolate/coffee malty-ness mf 3.0 - bitterness makes me pucker a bit , slows me down , it 's a sipping stout , slightly thin for a stout .

a : a careful pour yields an impressive , jet black beer with a dense brown head which hangs around a while .  m- thin to medium body- highly attenuated- with a coarse carbonation which delivers a slightly bloating feeling . could stand to have some softer carbonation .

damn , this smells good . big roasty malts compete with all that chocolate on the palate for quite a while , with nondescriptly bitter hops and a little alcohol warmth bringing up the rear . while the chocolate on the nose smells sweet and milky , in the mouth it 's an equal mix of bitter and sweet , which is just awesome . very well balanced , and you could drink it until the 11 % abv says otherwise .  well attenuated , yet with a little viscocity to it . the carbonation is so soft it is almost impereceptible .

for all intents and purposes it pours like duvel . a fantastically clear golden body , with a billowing soft white head .  mouthfeel is pretty fairly light with decent carbination .

truly majestic appearance - a very ruddy dark brown , almost bordering on black , with a smooth , creamy nitro head that left sheets of lace .  as it warms to maybe 50-55f , really no bitterness/hoppiness can be detected at the finish and i 'm immediately ready for another sip . i think the `` fleeting '' nature of this beer ( disappearing lace , no lingering bitterness ) contributes to the lack of feel -- but i suspect that is n't so much a goal for brewers of this style , so i do n't want to ding it in this category . this ale is at least on the level of samuel smith 's oatmeal stout and could have another or two .

received in trade from muenchenerkindl appearance is clear brown-to-black hue , huge thick brown head of creamy condensed foam dissipates to a moderate thickness , moderate lacing on the glass smell is toasted malts and alcohol mostly , tones of bitter chocolate and coffee , some toffee and earthy green tones taste is bizarre , so much so that i wonder if this may be a bad batch , mostly burnt bitter coffee malts and a strange load of dark fruits and grassy earthy hops , some sour buttermilk sensation creeps through , the finish is bitterly acidic with slight alcohol warming mouthfeel is medium-to-full bodied , creamy smooth texture borders on watery , low carbonation drinkability is poor , i have heard a lot of good things about this beer and would love to give it another shot , perhaps on draft , just in case this was a bad bottle .  as far as mouthfeel , it was rather carbonated and had a bit of a bite going down , especially when it was at its coldest .
a : dark brown , nearly opaque , lovely cappuccino-colored head that falls into a persistent cap with nice lacing .  mouthfeel is tough .

pours caramel with 3+ fingers of fluffed up khaki colored head . insane lacing & head retention s : plummy , some herbal hops , a touch of booze t : rich dark fruit herbal & woody hoppyness , plus much dryness & some boozey pine needles up front .  i absolutely love this beer . i hate the commercial light beers like bud light , miller and coors but i want to drink a flavorful light beer to save a few calories . sal fits the bill perfectly .
first of all , it was an amazing red with a pink head .  m - overcarbonated , light bodied for the style , but really good .

bottle courtesy of jjpm74 : poured a clear dark black color ale with a big foamy head with perfect retention and perfect lacing .  beer is thinner than i would have expected , or liked , but the flavor is there and the taste is long lasting . if it had a richer mouthfeel this beer would be top notch .

a-pours a beautiful ruby red with a thick , billowy cream colored head . there is some cascading and lacing left on the glass . i ca n't say enough how beautiful this beer looks , its amazing . s-grapefruit stands out the most from the hops .  creamy head and taste . drier than i expected yet not too hoppy ; which makes me happy ! the color is the dark murky chocolate you expect from a good stout , but lacks the `` fall effect '' one sees in guinness for example . overall a nice drinkable and easy on the palate brew !

the beer was black with a slight hunt of red at the very bottom . a 1cm sand colored head formed and slowly became a continual 0.5cm head .  the mouthfeel is a little on the thin side , but drinkability is excellent .
pours opaque black with a big fluffy brown head that retains well and laces the glass .  m- good carbonation . a little watery for an imperial stout .
darker than i 'm used to with a iipa but this looks nice . brilliantly clear .  m : less smooth than the iv ; it has a rubbery booze component that i do n't care for . otherwise fine .

the orange copper color is brillinat in my glass , and the head formation and retention is great . great lacing too .  feels too carbonated and light in the mouth . just an average mouthfeel though , not too bad .
the dark brown liquid shines with strobe like flashes of ruby red .  the body seems a little thin in my opinion , but otherwise , this is a substantial beverage all around .

s : fresh herbs . amazing . nothing like it .  taste- light medium to medium bodied . the only drawback would be that the body was not very thick as i was expecting . nothing bad , but nothing really amazing either .

it pours deep brown , almost black , with light head .  well done porter ... .looks the part with a creamy tan head atop a black body ... a very nice aroma greets my nose..roasted and sweetish ... milk chocolate as well as some subtle coffee notes milk chocolate and roasted malts are the big players on the taste but the java notes become a little more pronounced ... body is creamy and smooth and slightly thin ... i do n't exect regular ol porters to be high gravity monsters so this is fine with me ... it really drinks easily and quickly ... .

a : pours jet black . minimal frothy chocolate brown head that disappears quickly .  m - lot 's of carbonation is there making this really move . unfortunately it 's to the point of almost being painful . medium body . it 's sort of an odd one because of the carbonation .

this is an interesting concept , iam surprised there hasnt been more forays into melding the two styles.i poured into a weizen glass rather than my nonic for appearance and it poured nicely , hazed burnt orange tinged golden with a fluffy one and a half finger white head that left a broken ring of lace as it settled slowly.love the in your face citric hop aromas , really fresh , slight toasted wheat malt and clove as well.the mouthfeel was much thinner than expected and seemed to take a little of the flavor away , somewhat watery with decent shot of resiny/citric hop on the palate , toasted wheat malt again comes thru a little as well.if the mouthfeel was amped up a little this beer would be great but alas it isnt and the beer is just `` pretty good '' .  f - medium body but carbonation is very weak .

pour lets out a large , just off-white head head over a clear , tan body . excellent retention and lace . tons of carbonation makes this look like one refreshing , attractive lager .  this beer is supposed to be a german style pilsner . the first pilsner that the brewers den has ever made . the first thing one notices is the hops . a little bit too much hoppy aroma , flavor and bitterness for a true german pilsner but a great version of a american style craft brewed german pilsner . dry hopped with halletauer hops . another great uwe-beer .
beer is yellow and clear with a nice white head that has some retention . carbonation is moderate and steady , lots of lacing .  thin body , decent carbonation .

it smelled so good . the taste was definitely like coffee ... but with a sweetness to it .  more of the same in the finish , kept triggering my gag reflex medium bodied , slick with moderate carbonation , skewed way to sweet , needs some alcohol burn to mitigate this horrible drinkability .

bottle , a : pours a cloudy sun yellow , with a perfect cap of white foam , great retention , with extensive lacing .  the body does seema tad watery , i would expect more fo a `` fullness '' , but overall i feel the beer is a great scottish ale , overpoweringly malty , no hops that i could detect and pretty much no smoky presence which i can appreciate , since i 've had one too many smoky sottish style ales .

2 december 2005 , best before apr 06 mostly clear dark orange colour with a large dense whipped cream white head . looks impressive in the glass , the head rises well above the rim and holds its form remarkably well .  m - sharp carbination starts off this beer , and turns almost tart . it seems young .

gorgoues blurry bronze orange hue crowned with an immensely tall and loftly thickened spongey beige foam that sits like a hat that wo n't blow off in a strong wind .  m/d : a light body that is fairly creamy .

the tankhouse ale comes in a tall , skinny non-standard dark brown bottle with printed text and graphics instead of a paper label -- looks great on a shelf with others from the same brewery . the back of the bottle describes the beer 's colour as copper-red , but it looks more amber to me . poured into a pint glass with a nice foamy two-inch head .  mouthfeel is thin with just moderate carbonation .
a truly great looking beer .  mouthfeel is pretty thin as well .

pours a deep , dark brown that allows a fair amount of light through the periphery . a one-half inch light tan head reduces quickly , leaving generous amounts of thick lacing on the sides of my glass . by the end of this beer , large amounts of spotty lacing remain all over the inside of my globe . i am impressed with the appearance !  m- a little on the thin side and a little under carbonated . overall i thought this was a good octoberfest beer , spot on for its style , besides its mouthfeel .

cork marking 0205 ... poured a ruby , garnet color with a medium sized pink head and light lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel is pretty average , but not annoying . carbonation 's good , body on the thin side .
12oz bottle ... a : deep dark color with a milk chocolate mocha colored that never completely fades .  m : pretty darn thick and syrupy .
deep amber in color .  m - nice light carbonation and creaminess , but the body is a little light and watered down .

pours a deep amber color with a big , creamy beige head .  it 's rare that i ca n't even stomach a beer long enough to get a few sips down . this beer gave me one of those rare moments . the smell was a sour , and the taste was dirty and skunky . i did n't want to waste the pack , so i made a couple of michelada cocktails . they were actully quite tasty.. nothing like worcestershire and tabasco to make something taste better !

two finger tan head shows great retention . lots of web style lacing on the sides of the glass .  id love for this to have a heavier mouthfeel , but this is a darn good session beer for a cold night .

smell- this one has a really nice scent . some very sweet chocolaty caramel toasted or roasted malt .  s- old coffee grounds , very roasty t- coffee , roasted malt and vanilla , with a slight oak detection m- thick but not bcs thick , however your mouth will be coated in flavors .

clear garnet brown with a big , bountiful , buttercreme head that shows excellent durability and lacing . it really is a beautiful looking beer .  m : sharp at first , fizzy , but lights up as you hold it . still , a bit strong and that cuts down on how much you can have . d : i had 10oz with no problems , but a second might have gotten bothersome due to the fizz .

it is eerie how perfect this beer looks.. from that reverse cascade pour comes a perfectly consistent black liquid under a similar khaki head . stain is crazy thick and solid like the lace .  mouthfeel is medium-light .

the smell is pretty awesome . just a thick rich , perfect scent for the baltic porter . it is a nice beer , the flavor could be better , but overall it is enjoyable  unfortunately , the flavor and mouthfeel do n't fully deliver on what the aroma suggested . this is still a tasty beer but it 's a bit thinner than i hoped for and has a much stronger roast presence than i prefer .

poured a deep amberish copper with big carbonation and a dirty white head .  thanks kplynch for the bottle . color is orange amber with a variety of floral hops hitting the aroma . it 's on the lighter side , but tasty . just not really living up to the imperial in ipa . i 'd call it a well balanced , smooth ipa with notes of citrus and floral hops ...

produces a big tan head and the color is dark as night in hell ( or northern british columbia , perhaps ) . leaves wide splashes and thick strips of lace on the sides of the glass . looks great .  light-medium carbonation and medium bodied . piney hops and paint thinner nose . flavor starts with sweet malt but quickly goes to hop and finishes with a paint thinner aftertaste . overpriced at $ 1.50 for a 12oz bottle from manchester wine and liquors manchester , ct .

appears , smells and tastes basically the same as the first one i had a couple months back , which is to say that this is a decent beer but a very mediocre ipa . appearance & smell : it looks good in the glass as the creamy beige head rests softly atop the hazy copper colored body .  mouthfeel is a bit thin , with a little creaminess from the malt being nice , but not quite enough .
a - pour is a really nice thick oily black with a super creamy mocha head that is half a finger and never really fades . just rests atop it nicely . s - woah .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin .

the smell was also sweet and very well balanced . i prefer a little bit more bitterness in my beers but this is a respectable amber lager .  mouthfeel is fuzzy and fairly light and chablis-like with a slightly harsh lemony tartness on the tongue .

pours out to a clear dark caramel , with the highly flocculent yeast sticking firmly in the bottom of the bottle , forming a peaking meringue-like whipped head with superior retention and lacing .  m - fairly light and not all that carbonated ; really could use a bit of extra body .
poured out a beautifully clear orange tinted yellow with a nice frothy head and beads of carbonation continually rose to the surface .  the only place i would knock it down is in the mouthfeel .

this brew from yards starts out wonderfully by building expectations with a stellar appearance , but tanks back into the land of average thereafter . pours a great looking cloudy amber colour with a big creamy off-white head . nice stickiness and great overall appearance .  mildly thin body , but not alarmingly so .

stupendous nose . i found the taste to be not quite as amazing as the smell , but this is a really great and enjoyable quad . perhaps a little too much for my taste , but still really good .  mouthfeel : light for darker beer . nothing special . but as in mouthfeel , nothing here will blow your brains out .
pours dark , very dark , brown color with light , light , brown frothy 2 finger head .  m : medium bodied , but the carbonation is lacking .

the nose kills me it 's so good , making me very excited for the first sip . i could just stick my proboscis all the way in to the bottom of the glass and drink this through my nose it feels like . definitely a winner . great yeast character in both smell and taste .  m : light to mid bodied , little watery at first bit smooths out as it warms up .

appearance : the body was black as night with an abundance of small dark tan bubbles that fills the top half of the glass before slowly settling at the top of the glass . the head that forms is thick and creamy with a light tan color .  mouthfeel this beer is a bit thin for what i expect from an imperial stout .

dark fruit , specifically currant , dominates the smell . there is also a good dose of dark roasty malts and definitely creamy chocolate . its even nicer that it is both cheap and available .  it 's very refreshing to the mouth ( do i say that about all the beers i review ? ) , with small , present carbonation and what i 'm finding to be a lighter body than i expected from a wee heavy . by virtue of this lighter than expected body , however , this is an extremely drinkable beer .
poured into a pint glass.. copper orange color , fizzy head at the perfect proportion .  m - slick and slightly thin .

tried this on a whim ... made with raisins and beet sugars , i was hoping for an interesting experiment , but ended up finding one of my favorite recent discoveries , and the best so far by the amazing brewers at dogfish head . the color alone is an experience . i would paint my apartment with that rich , warm , brown-red color .  mouthfeel-par the course for the style , maybe a a little watery thin but nothing that really impacts the drinking , besides , it 's a wit , it 's not supposed to feel heavy .

the pour on this is awesome like every nitro can , nice tiger stripes as it slowly settles out , then you get theat signature nitro one finger white head .  the body was medium full and just a bit less than expected from an imperial stout . missing body for an imperial stout , it is nonetheless a very nice an drinkable beer .

smells of toast and caramel , with loads of hop aroma . amazing hop character is what i taste upfront , backed by biscuit and warming sensations from the alcohol .  mouthfeel is flattish and thin , does n't really compliment the chocolateyness .

very nice aroma of sweet malt , honey , light hops , and toffee . very good for the style .  some bitter to this as well there is still some hops to it a little syrupy but there is some carbonation to it so it is bearable .
crystal brown `` loverly '' color . quite effervescent - copious amounts of sea-foam looking suds .  i would have expected a little more body in this beer . a little skinny for my tastes .

pours a dark , black coffee color with three fingers width of mocha colored head . reduced to a fingers width over consumption . great head retention and the lacing was so thick it just caked the sides of the glass .  light carbonation and light-medium bodied . starts almost sweet but hops dominate , boring , finish is dry and slightly bitter . brewed aug 12 , 2005 . $ 1.79 for a 330ml bottle from lina 's beverages painesville , oh .
what a great looking beer , stylistically . an almost opaque reddish brown with a nice big frothy tan head .  mouthfeel is a bit on the thin side , carbonation level is appropriate for the style .

a : moderate pour down the center of the glass leads to 5 finger head ! wow this head is not going anywhere , sticks around forever . lots of carbonation in this one . looks like it could be unfiltered .  pours black but with some deep red highlights with a slight off-white head that is gone in a flash leaving nothing behind , milk chocolate is very prevelant in the aroma with a little smokiness and a roasted coffee hint.nice deeply roasted flavor with big doses of cocoa and smoke , alot of flavor melding going on but seemed a little light in the mouthfeel department otheriwise a top notch brew.a easy drinker with alot of flavor needs a little tweaking to be great in my opinion .

appearance- poured a luscious fist of a head into my mug . the head retention was very good . the beer poured a cloudy , deep garnet brown with a lot of lacing .  mouthfeel - medium..maybe a little on the more watery side , but still creamy-ish .

quite a beauty in the glass . clear , gold and with a thick , rocky head that leaves a ton of lacing in its wake .  hahahahahaha bourbon my as- . this beer tastes like the worst cake frosting i 've ever had . body 's not bad either if you can get by the taste .

) so i 'll try to play be the rules this time : appearance : solid black and thick as hell ( great looking stout ) smell : mixture of spoiled prune juice and nail polish remover taste : something is wrong with this .  mouthfeel is pretty sharp and fizzy from the bubbles . average kind of body , but mostly just bubbly .
a fantastic looking beer . really grand looking stuff .  m - syrapy with a decent carbonation .

s : lots of malt , caramel sweetness , some boozey spice in there , some darker fruit . very sweet . t : for such an aggressively sweet smell , the taste is a bit on the bitter side for a barleywine .  mouthfeel - low carbonation .

whatever it is , it 's complex and wonderful . t-nice balance of a stout ( i know there 's a trace of that in here ) with subtle sour characteristics : seems to be cherry . very nice finish .  it starts out thin with the wheat malt taking center stage then gets spicier as it goes . it finishes with a lot of banana and touch of yeast that lingers a fair amount for a lighter beer . the rest : a solid , tasty wit ; it checks all of the boxes of the style , and does it pretty well .
a - looks nice .  mouthfeel : medium body with a bit of oil that leaves a coat .

had this out of a bottle poured into a dfh pint glass ... a : copper color with a nice 2 finger white head . the lacing on this one is fantastic ... s : smells of floral hops and sweet malt .  m : yeah , i guess .

the strong aroma of pumpkin and ginger was really promising on this one , but the flavor really did n't deliver .  surprisingly dry finish in the back m - a bit think , could use some more bubbles or hops to round out the malt a bit .

22 oz bomber poured into a duvel tulip glass . massively massive head . that is fantastic head ! the color itself was a very dark ruby red color . that 's an interesting color for an ipa , which i 'm guessing is due to the rye .  mouthfeel - kinda effervescent . nothing exceptional .

aroma of hops , spice , coriander , lemon , and some grapefruit . although for being a wheat beer this is somewhat of the mark but for an interpretation this is excellent . citrus overtones , with few hints of bread . overall this is great .  mouthfeel - average crispness , moderately thin body , i 'm okay with it .

aroma is strong and boozy , tons of whiskey .  m - medium body with a pretty smooth texture , but mouthfeel is a little thin for a porter . body is a little thin , but the aromas and flavors are quite pleasant .

pours out of the dark clad bottle pure black with just a few hints of ruby around the edges . the rocky tan head lasts forever and leaves a lot of lace patches behind .  this was highly carbonated which produced a slighlty unpleasant tingling mouthfeel .

this beer pours a brilliant brown amber with a sandy off-white film that left some nice lace behind . this is truly an attractive beer .  m- a thin body- fully attenuated with no carbonation at all ... which is normal for the style , particularly when served by cask . quite possibly the best kriek lambic i have ever had !

a - pours orange with 2 fingers of white head . refuses to dissipate and leaves beautiful lacing .  first of all , any beer that has rock , paper , scissors bottle caps is a shoe-in in my book . this beer pours nicely to be a nice golden -yellow ( this is actually the first time i have drank this not straight from the bottle ) small head , disappears right away . tiny bubbles , smell of good malts . great drinkability great beer , great brewery , great price
a : solid bock appearance with a crisp , clear brown color with amber hues . a soft white head and not too much carbonation .  mouthfeel : medium bodied . low carbonation .

pitch black color , topped with a very dark tan , thick head .  the taste is about the same , with a distinct nut flavor . goes down pretty easy , but there is a lot of carbonation here , and you can distinctly see many small bubbles rising up from behind the brown color . overall , this is a pretty good beer , and a nice looking one . i recommend it .
the poured beer looks great too .  aside from the dry end this is an easy to drink beer with an average mouth .

very nice , actually ... my mouth is watering . the very beginning of the taste is good , but that first sweetroastiness is eclipsed by a strong bitterness and waxing dryness that detract from the experience such a good smell . man .  m - heavy , almost cough-syrup consistency with light carbonation .
sweet chocolaty aroma .  the body seems a bit lighter than i would have expected .

pours pitch black and completely opaque without even the slightest bit of lighter hues when held to a light source and a frothy dark chocolate neige/brown head that slowly fades into a lasting ring . large chunks of soapy lacing are left behind .  the mouth feel is a bit light for such a porter .

first off this beer smells great ... it 's right up there with green flash for hoppy aroma and complextiy . this is very solid and drinkable do n't get me wrong but it 's under carbonated and there is too much malt finish to make it truly great . when the beer makes contact with your taste buds you get a nice hoppy dose of citrus but it fades so quickly and the carbonation flattens before you swallow the beer that you do not feel total satisfaction upon drinking .  m - medium bodied with higher than average carbonation . it looks and feels a little chalky .

this is what beer should look like ... medium orange with a incredibly mesmerizing swirl of carbonation that doesnt quit for anything rising into a thin 1/4-inch but cozy blanket of off-white puckered foam .  maybe a bit watery because of the low alcohol content ? ? ? but samuel adams boston lager is about the same abv and to me thats more full bodied and a better malt backing .

coming from my hometown , i was psyched to try this one , and it looks like my excitement was justified . pours dark as night with a wondeful nutty coffee aroma .  there is very little carbonation , so the mouthfeel reminds me of a generic malt beverage .

poured with a large 3f soapy off-white head over a mostly clear , burnt orange body , with tons of visible carbonation and plenty of lacing .  it seems to say , above , that it 's cask ... it was certainly carbonated when we tried it - just not highly carbed . a bit light in the mouthfeel like all of the brutopia beers we tried .

zero lacing & head retention s : awesome sour/lactic odors t : an almost sugary sweetness is quickly steamrolled by sourness tartness & dry/wood notes .  i thought i did n't like saisons until i tried this one . kind of a mild coconutty taste , almost pina colada like ? i 'm going to revisit this one for sure whenever i get a chance .
the pour was a bright and brilliant clear red and was topped off with a sparse off white head .  mouthfeel - a bit of a strange after taste but very crisp .

pours a dark , hazy mahogany with a giant off-white head . lacing is just about perfect .  the only real complaint i have with this beer is that it is just too thin ... i do n't buy that this is an ris ... if this was just an american stout , the thinner body would be suitable , but it 's just not on an imperial stout .

we evaluated every stout we could get out hands on here in the western us . we did the same with the non-us stouts we could find . obsidian stout had a robust roasted flavor but a very strong , bitter late bite that ruined it for us .  medium bodied , but has too much carbonation for my liking .
the head is full and thick fading a lingering creme like a great espresso . lacing on the glass is wonderful .  the mouthfeel is a little thin for the style but its still a fairly minor flaw .
appearance : pours a dark auburn body with 2-3 fingers worth of light tan head .  slightly dry malt/biscuit finish m & d : slightly thin mouthfeel , but overall a nice beer .

appearance is excellent , very dark and black like a stout should be .  surprising amount of carbination gets you with the first sip , it foams up in your mouth . but the body is alot less than i was expecting ... not think , just mostly carbination on top of a thin to medium body.. ? the flavors linger on your tongue , mainly at the back sides .
appearance - rich dark amber brown with a cream head . beautiful label on bottle .  m - murky with a low carbonation and a lingering sour .

this is incredibly intense , but also incredibly appealing . excellent !  mouthfeel/drinkability- a very thin beer in general , the carbonation breaks early in the mouth , then goes quickly and smoothly down the throat .
appearance is beautiful - a deep red/gold ( like a maple tree changing colors ) with a nice sticky head .  light bodied , and somewhat flat , though perhaps that is just this bottle ?

pours a super clear fiery reddish orange . a creamy eggshell colored head sits on top and provides some awesome sticky lacing .  makes it look like a blue moon ... i dont know just dont see the drinkability and mouthfeel to be good at all ... it was one and done for me ... .

samuel adam 's longshot weizenbock pours a couple fingers of dense tan foam over a deep brown brew . the nose is mellow and spicy- clove and banana , carbonation is medium and steady . this one does not touch aventinus- the benchmark , as far as i 'm concerned , for this style , but it 's still a way up there .  it 's pretty light bodied with a low level of carbonation .

appearance : pours a clear dark ruby-brown color with a 2 finger , dark cream colored head . the head settles to 1/2 inch and sticks around the whole time leaving a moderate amount of lacing on the glass .  very little carbonation , the beer feels light but also dense .

had this on tap at the brick store pub , served in a regensboog flute . poured a beautifully hazy dark golden with a great pure white head with finely beaded bubbles and that leaves some very fine lacing .  mouthfeel was slightly on the thin side , not quite watery , but close .

the nitro can widget leads to a beautiful cascading effect , pefectly dark beer , with the fluffy white head . looks fake it looks so good .  however the taste is more mellow than the smell and easier than expected to drink . it would go great with dark meats such as beef and pork . not something to drink often but a great change from the usual and like nothing i have ever tasted . it is without a must try .
poured into an imperial pint glass , formed a 1 '' beige head over the slightly cloudy reddish amber brew . pillowy head recedes very slowly , with plenty of chunky lacing .  the mouthfeel is thin .

smells pretty good ; slightly sweet , with mild malts and citrussy hops making up the aroma .  the carbonation is just a bit prickly , it is n't the fullest , but what should expect . this one goes down smoothly , with the only turn-off being the carbonation .

bottle : poured a clear deep brown color ale with a nice huge foamy head with good retention and some nice lacing .  m : somewhat thin and slick ; however , you feel the heaviness in your stomach halfway down the glass .

a beautiful cloudy-golden color with an explosive 2.5 inch head that lasted for a few minutes .  it has a surprisingly thin body for such a bourbon and malty beast . also the carbonation is a bit higher then i would like for the style .

it 's a nice color , like a pretty standard pale ale/ipa . great retention ... good lacing . so it looks great ... aaaand now we fall apart ... why does this smell like garlic ?  should you drink this warm or cold ? when it 's cold the flavors are : dark chocolate , coffee , heavily roasted to burnt malt , and bitter hops . when it 's warm the flavors are more like : sweet chocolate , maybe some sort of fruit , coffee , heavily roasted malt , and not so bitter hops . i perfer the sweeter chocolate , not burnt malt , and less bitter hops flavor when it 's warm .

aroma of toasted bread and roasting chestnuts with a strong coppery head . strong roast nuts , toasted almonds , caramel and hints of apricot and cherry pull together to give a beer that is a little different with each sip as the palate becomes accustomed .  the mouthfeel is quite thin , but leaves a good chocolaty flavor on the back of the palate .
long lasting white , health head , opaque orange-yellow body .  m - medium , slight carbonation , blah .

a : pours a clear golden-amber , tons of carb bubbles flowing up through to support two fingers of foamy white head .  the aroma is hoppy and earthy with some fruity notes , reminds me a bit of orval in this sense . the flavor has a nice character of fruity hopes and a mild malt sweetness , but the beer is dominantly dry . there is a very mild tartness here but generally the beer is dominated by a blend between some spicy yeast notes and pleasant hop bitterness .
this stout pours with a dark brown to black body toped by a medium thick , brown head with lots of lacing .  the body of it was rather thin .

this is the most unusual and most pleasant smelling lager that i ever had the pleasure to inhale . i loved it . there are lots of flavors here for your tongue to enjoy . the best part is nothing over dominates .  m - not bad , but a little thinner than i was hoping for .

11.2 ounce bottle poured into pint glass two finger , tan head last thoughout the duration of the drink . mouthfeels is a bit thin and watery for a stout ... .just average . overall , this stout will do in a pinch , but not in my top 10 .  not very full in the mouth , a bit thin in my opinion .

smutty ipa pours a stunning bright orange , with a nice creamy white cap that hangs around for a minute before coating my glass with lace . absolutely gorgeous .  m- a solid amount of carbonation coupled with a lighter body makes this drink overall a little too light for my personal tastes .
appearance - wow at first it looked like a coffee milk shake , but after it settled it was a pitch black color with a creamy tan head .  it feels just a bit watery .
when held to light , has a reddish hue . this beer looks great . head retention is good , and there is some great lacing from the hops .  mouthfeel is flat feeling and a little thin .

the beer pours jet-black with the head modest in size and a light chocolate in color , the consistency creamy and the resultant lace a fine sheet to conceal the glass .  m- mouth is a little on the light side for a stout .
good retention and strong lacing . very nice .  ( m ) - a very high carbonation level .

this ale pours a copper brown with lots of carbonation and has a big head .  mf : thin for a baltic porter , the big flavor makes up for this , medium carbonation d : this beer has a ton of things going on and i must say it is well executed .
terrific retention , heavy lace . gorgeous lager .  looking at it you 'd expect a stout , smelling it you 'd expect it to be sweet - it 's neither - and it feels thinner than expected as well !

copper to gold ... lots of light flickering through and a rocky 3/4 '' bright white head ... aroma is awesome ... truly great . some spicy cinnamon and grassy hops ... herbaceous in a very cool herbaceous way with a a hint of basil and nosefull of dill . peppery and delicious . awesome .  m : smooth and creamy , though lacking the body found in non-nitro stouts , not bad though , a fuller body than guinness .

wonderful hop aroma , nice and citrusy with some pine malt and spice .  the body is surprisingly thick and coating with a rich slick mouth feel .

bold assertive bittering , much like what i picked up in the aroma , with some herbal and floral hopping as well . the hops are really strong here , possibly the hoppiest i 've had .  medium carbonation and fairly full bodied ; with a huge creamy and slick mouthfeel , that drinks super smoothly for being over 11 % . big creamy and lush body ; with a very dessert-like flavor profile ; without being cloyingly sweet .

very nice . this was my final beer . not nearly the flavor i was expecting based on the wonderful aroma . easy to drink but need a little more uuuumph !  love the mouthfeel . smooth and creamy through the swallow , with a very mild , slightly dry finish and pleasant aftertaste .

i thought this smelled wonderful , these guys do get the aromas ' of there brews right .  mouthfeel , exceptional , like champagne ... exactly , close your eyes its champagne .

rather disappointing after such a wonderful aroma from this beer .  mouthfeel is magnificent . again , like a thin syrup .

smells absolutely fantastic . super-hop odor with sugary sweetness too .  m : perfect mouthfeel , light , crisp and very refreshing . excellent carbonation .
one of the better smelling beers i 've come across .  mouthfeel is lush and satiny smooth as the beer effortlessly flows down . mellow carbonation adds to the ease of drinkability here .

very attractive smell , grainy with some yeast and a fresh sweetness .  excellent body that just coats your mouth .

that said : the aroma is quite special , and definitely brings memories of the holiday season . it 's almost nice enough to enjoy by itself ; reading a leatherbound copy of `` a christmas carol '' in front of a low burning fireplace with its sweet and spicy aroma continually reminding you that your glass is sitting beside you . the head is pillow-like at first , but receedes to a nice 1/16 '' that lasts to the end . this year 's seems to have much less hop flavor and a reduced bitterness which gives the malt and spice a rounder flavor .  mouthfeel/drinkability- just when i thought the perfect mouthfeel of a belgian ale was locked up with tripel karmeliet , this beer dazzles with a sublime , gentle texture that lasts throughout the entire duration in the mouth . absolute perfection , it further emphasizes the already impressive quality of the beer .
s - world class . raisins , sweet fruitiness , definitely some oak - it just smells like dessert .  indulgent , creamy mouthfeel . and i really ca n't get over how pleasurable the mouthfeel is .

decadent as well , somewhat like chocolate covered cherry cordials . absolutely fantastic in the nose ! syrupy and mellow with buttery brown bread and nice fruit : apple , berry , citrus , and fig . sweet and woody and not terribly pronounced provided the outstanding nose . mild hops and vanilla with a ghost-like smoke note . very complex and earthy but rather understated . very nice however . a unique and enjoyable rendition of the style .  mouthfeel is also top notch . low carbonation that goes down very smooth .

s - strong milk chocolate flavor , more creamy than bitter . good espresso addition . d - tastes , smells , feels , and looks like a stout , so why not call it one ?  near perfect carbonation and body .

very nice . whoa ! it 's tastes ok but so far off from the fantastic nose . the sweet grains you smell taste like wet toast wrapped in paper towel . the flavor has a slight mustiness to it that i find to be very boring .  mf - this it where this beer shines the most to me . very nice carbonation that tickles your mouth as you savor it . also reminds me in some ways of an eisbock albeit less vinuous and more carbonated and roasty .

stunning citrusy orange-grapefruit-lemon-passion fruit and pine aroma . could sniff this one all day . exceptional aroma carries the day here .  mouthfeel is perfection , smooth , crisp , with just the right amount of carbonation ... and the tartness in the finish leaves you wanting to pour more of that big bottle .

the aroma was of fresh harvest hops . in fact the lovely dry hopped aroma of this beer made my mouth salivate wildly in anticipation of the wonderful nectar that was forthcoming .  m - this is what really sets this beer apart for me . incredibly creamy and thick mouth feel .

awesome smell ... this one really shows off a great bouquet of hops . about as good as it gets here . still good , with the great hop character , but not quite as good as the nose .  the beer didnt quite taste as good as it looked , but it was still quite pleasently sweet and i highly enjoyed the creamy mouthfeel it had .

a : nearly clear off-white yellow with puffy fine bubbles head that kept it all the way , great lacing s : mild nose with spicy yeast , some soft floral aspects too t : traditional saison with earthy/floral qualities probably from elderflowers , noticeable hop bite in finish , hops were more than normal for a saison but not offensive m : decent mouthfeel with all the qualities of a saison ( yeasty , spritzy ) but with stronger hop finish  mouthfeel was perfect for me ... .slightly tingly , but at the same time silky smooth and gentle on the palate .

strong aromas of roasted dark chocolate , malts , coffee , whisky . great . taste is full bodied and powerful ; flavors of coffee , malt , unsweetened dark chocolate , a touch of hops , warming alcohol notes likely from the bourbon ageing .  m - very full bodied , nearly stout full .

i get some raisin and vanilla in the middle and molasses , chocolate , and black licorice on the backend . awesome ! perfect !  high carbonation . probably the silkiest body in a dipa i 've ever encountered .

the nose of the beer was simply amazing ! probably the best smelling beer i have ever experienced . something about it was very comforting , it reminded me of buttered toast with cinnamon and sugar piled on then a hint of alcohol .  m : i love the low carbonation as it works really well here .

very enticing ... s- thank you surly for this aroma that i have now gotten to experience . in your face grapefruit , pineapple , oranges , and just a tiny bit of pine/wood to add some complexity . i literally sense no malt sweetness in this to back up the hop aroma like you get in other beers , and that is great by me ! t/m- very bitter forward . o- very good ipa .  the mouthfeel is perfect for a stout .

nice ! maybe this one suffers from where i am in my own personal `` beer journey , '' but i 'm getting a little tired of ipa that smell great & fragrant & then assault you with aggressive , tongue-battering bitterness .  the mouthfeel is exceptional -- thick , chewy , syrupy , andincredibly smooth .
smell : one of the best hefe smells ever , since i 'm not the biggest banana-hef fan .  smooth creamy mouthfeel , it 's a satisfying brew for my palate . very good stuff .
citrus , raspberry , lemon , and a hint of oak .  mouth is silky smooth with a full body a great carbonation , did n't go flat like alot of darker brews have .
this beer looks and smells great . the taste is very average - i was expecting more with a name like ambergeddon - still good .  it 's pretty full bodied and very smooth with a clean , dry finish .

a beautiful copper colour , with hints of candied pear in the nose and some peach . nice , full mouthfeel but the taste lacked the wholesome maltiness that i expect in a bitter .  creamy , smooth mouthfeel goes excellent with the flavor profile .

love it . my type of stout aroma . t : more balanced than the smell .  light to medium in body , with significant carbonation , and an amazing palate to mingle with the generous abv make the mouthfeel very impressive . one of my favorite styles , and certainly one of my favorites amongst it .
wow , awesome aroma for this beer . really nice pour , medium tan head . really unique brew .  m : incredible mouthfeel .

pleasantly fragrant . slightly bready with some fruitiness and hop bitterness in the afteraste . taste does n't quite live up to the aroma , but it 's very drinkable .  creamy , oily , perfect weight .

strong fresh hop smell -- very much like a double ipa . surprisingly , there 's very little hop up front .  simpler flavor and wonderful mouthfeel enhance the drinkability ; but it is slightly boring .
the smell is really good , warm , but hopeful of spring , because it has just the right amount of alcohol bite .  m- full bodied , creamy , thick luscious mouthfeel .

aroma is bright with citrus and syrupy with alpha acid promise . this is without a doubt the most unique and hardest nose to describe that i have ever come across .  mouthfeel is highly pleasurable , with perfectly gauged carbonation .

22oz bottle ( best by july 2010 ) poured into a dogfish head signature glass . a - pours a mostly clear bright orange with a beautiful whipped creamy one finger cap of foam with excellent retention . when the beer level falls ( the head never really goes away and stays with the beer throughout the glass ) , it leaves behind lots of sticky spiderwebs of lacing on the glass .  the mouthfeel was the best part of this beer .

aromas of sour cherries , malt vinegar and rhubarb come across very strongly with subtle notes of vanilla and rich chocolate fudge ( likely from the oak ) in the background . as it continues to warm , i pick up some definite cheese aromas as well ( fresh gorgonzola comes to mind ) .  mouthfeel is full and round .

very nice and refreshing . the flavor is saison earthy funk with a little sweet fruit and a little spice .  on the palate , this beer is very much alive still with plenty of carbonation , a full body , and a super-long finish . the alcohol is almost non-existent on the palate , leading to a very balanced and easy-drinking ( although fairly heavy ) beer .

smells great , black licorice and sweet molasses malt . a little pine coming through on the nose now too . flavors remain unbalanced and even a tad harsh on the front end .  incredibly smooth and creamy in the mouth .

the massive , whipped egg-white head on this tarnished gold beer offers up an awesome bouquet of fresh lemon . lemongrass , herbal hops , sour yeastiness , white pepper , and just a touch of pine or maybe even juniper .  creamy , almost soupy mouthfeel .

splendid , rich bouquet of floral hops , very aromatic . too overfiltered for my liking , but this does n't seem to effect the potency all that much .  big , smooth , and slick . this is a particularly rich baltic porter . very dark , dense , and well crafted .

i love the aroma . t : to bad non of the aroma carried over . the nose is really amazing , but not much else stands out .  texture is silky smooth and it does n't feel nearly as strong as it actually is .

the smell is terrific . loaded with citrus scents and a nice blend of bitter and floral hops , this one has the makings of a winner already .  mouthfeel was incredibly creamy .

aroma : smells amazing . tons of grapefruit and sweet cotton candy in the aroma . drinkability : this is an amazing ipa , full of great west coast hop aromas and flavors . it 's easy drinking , and quite delightful .  mf is creamy , and quite nice .

very , very enticing . the taste is grapefruit rind , bready , biscuit malt , some pithy tropical fruit , and a bit of pine .  it possesses the best mouthfeel i 've yet to come across , rich and velvety , it just rolls over the palate and tongue , and goes down incredibly smooth .
a-full and wonderful piney , resiny hops full the nose with some faint malt in the background . nice lacing .  the mouthfeel is where this beer really , really shines .
